Their first stop on a busy day of public engagements was a tour of the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. The Unesco World Heritage Site is made up of some 40,000 large black basalt columns which protrude from the sea. It was the Royal couple's first visit to Northern Ireland's best known tourist attraction. The causeway formed when molten rock was forced up through fissures in the earth to form a lava plateau. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh then travelled to the nearby village of Bushmills to commemorate local soldier Robert Quigg. He won a Victoria Cross for bravery during the Battle of the Somme. Sgt Quigg was given the highest military award for valour after going out into the line of fire to search for his commanding officer. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh unveiled a statue of the soldier as well as a commemorative stone. His grandnephew, Leonard Quigg, also gave a short address. From there, the Royal couple moved on to a reception at Portrush Golf Club as guests of the mayor for the Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council. Afterwards, they took a journey back in time as they travelled on a steam train from Coleraine, County Londonderry, to the village of Bellarena. Large crowds gathered in Coleraine to greet the couple as they boarded the five-carriage train, built in 1932. The Royal guests were accompanied by local schoolchildren as they travelled to Bellarena, where the Queen officially opened the village's new train station. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh first made the same journey along the historic Coleraine to Londonderry railway line in 1953 - the year of her coronation. The original station had opened a century earlier in 1853. Earlier this year, two new railway platforms opened in Bellarena, as part of a Â£46m upgrade to the Coleraine to Londonderry railway line. On her arrival in the village, the Queen unveiled a plaque marking the new development. Wellwishers lined the route, waving union flags and cheering. On Monday, the Royal visitor met Northern Ireland's first and deputy first ministers at Hillsborough Castle in County Down. Matthew Eteson is on trial at Preston Crown Court for the manslaughter by gross negligence of Kelly Webster, 36, and Lauren Thornton. The pair died in their sleep aboard a boat on Windermere in April 2013. Mr Eteson, 42, from Hale in Greater Manchester, denies the charge. The family had gone to the Lake District for the Easter bank holiday weekend to celebrate a friend's birthday. But on the afternoon of 1 April, Mr Eteson removed the generator from the deck and used it to power a 1kW fan heater to heat the sleeping quarter, prosecutor Mr Graham Reeds QC said. The court was told that there had been no warning to the build-up of the toxic gas because the carbon monoxide sensors had previously been disabled. Mr Reeds said the mother and daughter, both from Leyland in Lancashire, were found dead in their sleeping positions aboard the the second-hand Bayliner 285 motor cruiser Arniston, with fatal levels of carbon monoxide in their bodies. Mr Eteson, who had been sleeping in a separate compartment further away from the generator also succumbed to the effects of carbon monoxide poisoning but did awake to find the bodies. The court also heard Mr Eteson, a qualified gas fitter, had made some amendments to the generator and its exhaust, which experts subsequently deemed to be "dangerous". Ms Webster's mother, Nia Webster, had previously asked Mr Eteson about carbon monoxide sensors. He told her they were not working and his partner would unplug a portable detector whenever she was cooking. The trial continues.

It said O negative blood made up 12% of transfers, although only 7% of people in the UK had that blood type. Meanwhile, B negative blood is needed for ethnic groups. The NHSBT said ethnic minority groups, who were more likely to have B negative blood, were more prone to sickle cell anaemia, where misshapen blood cells could block blood vessels, causing an early death. It also said such groups were more at risk of developing thalassemia, a group of inherited blood disorders that hindered the blood's ability to carry oxygen. Only 2% of Britain's population were B negative, but hospitals had used 6% more of this blood type in the past last four weeks than the same period last year, said the NHSBT. B negative blood was useful as it could be used for both B negative and B positive patients, the organisation said. Donna Batty, donor relations manager at the NHSBT, asked donors to come forward in the "next few days". She said stocks of "these vulnerable groups" were "lower than we would like". Ms Batty added: "We are also asking donors of those blood groups who have an appointment coming up to keep it. "We hope our fantastic donors respond to this appeal and that they bear with us if there are slightly longer waits than normal on session as a result." In total, 4% of the UK's population currently donate blood. Jon Latham is assistant director of marketing of NHSBT said that ideally they wanted "first-time donors" to come forward. He said: "The bigger the database we have for people willing to donate, the easier it us for us to call upon them at times of the year when when we have a need for a particular group." However, recruiters said success was threatened by declining candidate availability as employers struggled to bring in the skills they need. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) said whichever party formed a government after the general election on 8 June must safeguard access to workers the country needs from abroad, as well as invest in UK jobseekers. The jobs report found growth in permanent appointments continued for the third month running in April, with the fastest rate of expansion for 21 months. This contrasted with a slowdown recorded across the UK as a whole. There was also a sharp increase in temporary placements - the steepest since August 2014. However, the availability of workers fell further in April, with the sharpest drop in the availability of permanent staff in nine months. Meanwhile, availability of Scottish temporary candidates declined at the quickest pace in nearly two years. The IT and computing, nursing/medical/care and hotel and catering sectors saw the highest growth in demand for permanent staff, while nursing/medical/care, IT and computing and engineering and construction led the way for temporary staff. The report also found that average salaries for permanent starters in Scotland rose sharply in April, while the rate at which temporary pay increased in Scotland was the fastest recorded for a year. REC chief executive Kevin Green said: "The resurgence of the Scottish jobs market continues for the third month running. "Demand for temporary staff is at the highest level recorded in almost 10 years as employers seek to manage Brexit uncertainty and meet consumer demand. "News that starting salaries for permanent roles are increasing will also be welcome - there's a lot to feel good about north of the border." He added: "Declining candidate availability is a threat to this success, because employers are struggling to bring in the skills they need. "If British business is to thrive, then whichever party forms a government after 8 June needs to address the ever-shrinking pool of suitable candidates by investing in skills and career advice for UK jobseekers

The new charity will manage the National Heritage Collection, which includes Stonehenge and Dover Castle. The government currently contributes £22m annually towards the collection. The aim is for the charity to eventually become self sufficient. Other powers such as listing buildings will remain government funded. The new official body, which will also advise on planning, has a working name of the National Heritage Protection Service. The new charity will still be called English Heritage and the 420 sites in the National Heritage Collection - which include London's Kenwood House, and Charles Darwin's home in Kent - will remain in public ownership. Government funding for the charity will be tapered down from 2015 eventually to nothing, meaning it will have more freedom than now to generate income from commercial activities and philanthropic donations. Some of the £80m awarded by the government will help to set up the charity so it will be fully operational by March 2015. In a statement, the government agency described the planned changes, which will be subject to a consultation, as "an excellent outcome". "This year we have been celebrating 100 years of state protection for heritage and today's announcement sets the scene for the next century. "The government's £80m investment and the creation of the new charity will help us preserve the National Heritage Collection for the future, be true to the story of the places we look after, to aim for the highest standards in everything we do from our conservation work to the way we run our events and to provide an experience that brings the story of England alive." The announcement came as the government said there would be cuts of up to 5% in funding for museums and the arts in the Spending Review for 2015-2016.

The court was told Kelly took a train to Edinburgh having used Ms Beattie's bank card to steal Â£300 from his victim's bank account. The victim's body was found by her daughter, who had failed to establish contact, on 25 May. Kelly apparently slept rough in Edinburgh until 28 May when he attended a GP surgery and confessed to killing Ms Beattie. Kelly told a doctor that "something bad has happened" adding: "I think I killed her." He went on: "I remember fighting and grabbing her around the neck. According to the OUP, new technology is increasingly at the centre of the children's lives but how they are writing about it is changing fast. Words including email, mobile and Facebook are in decline, it said. They are being replaced by the likes of Instagram, Snapchat and emoji. And the word television has now been superseded by phone. The use of the hashtag symbol # to add an extra meaning or comment at the end of a sentence has become commonplace. #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta at the Oxford University Press said: "This has been a significant change in usage in this year, 2015. "The 1914 eruption measured about 1.5km cubed in volume," said the study's lead author Dr James Hickey, who has now joined the University of Exeter's Camborne School of Mines. Their research showed that 14 million cubic metres of magma is accumulating each year, enough to fill London's Wembley Stadium 3.5 times over. They added that the rate at which the magma is accumulating is faster than it can be expelled in its regular smaller eruptions, which led them to infer that a major eruption is likely in the next 30 years. They made these assessments based on new ways of studying and modelling the volcano's magma reservoir. Scientists say they hope these findings can help authorities plan for major eruptions. Regina Hungerford, 56, denied hitting a 17-year-old as he listened to music in her class at Merthyr Tydfil College. Nevertheless, a disciplinary panel determined that contact with the student was probably made and her conduct had been "unacceptable." On Thursday, the Education Workforce Council issued the suspension, stating: "The public interest is in favour of her being able to teach again." Mrs. Hungerford admitted shouting and slamming a book on the desk of the "provocative and disruptive" teenager as he listened to rap music in her classroom, but always denied striking his head. She was acquitted, on appeal, of a criminal charge for assaulting the pupil during a maths lesson for those with learning difficulties. However, in November, a disciplinary panel found, on the balance of probabilities, she had made physical contact with the pupil on the head or hand. The panel concluded she had "acted in an inappropriate way" and ruled it constituted professional misconduct. During the hearing, the mother-of-three pleaded to save her "very rewarding" career. She described how the allegations had "ruined her life," calling it a "miscarriage of justice," but affirmed her wish to continue teaching. On Thursday, Mrs. Hungerford was informed she would be suspended from the teaching register for four months, though she will be allowed to return after completing a behaviour-management course. Panel chairman Gareth Roberts said it was the appropriate sanction to "allow her to return to teaching within a short period of time." He added: "The public interest is in favour of her being able to teach again."

Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary (HMIC) declared the force's staffing levels "fragile" and urged the rapid implementation of improvement plans. This inspection occurred after HMIC's criticism last year regarding the force's response to government spending cuts. Police and Crime Commissioner Olly Martins labeled the report "out of date." Previously, Bedfordshire Police was judged "requiring improvement" in HMIC's "Policing in Austerity: Meeting the Challenge" report last year. Inspectors, who had indicated the force would be "monitored closely," returned in October and observed its performance was not on par with similar forces. They pinpointed problems in the force control room, although they noted a recent staff increase should lead to their resolution. The report characterized staffing as "fragile but improving" and, despite recruitment, questioned the force's investment in preventative measures to reduce demand, raising concern that "it may not be tackling longer-term issues." Inspectors recommended the force implement its policing improvement plans "more quickly" and "in an affordable way" while ensuring service effectiveness. However, they also stated the force was "moving in the right direction and the pace of change is increasing." Mr. Martins argued that publishing "out-of-date snapshots" like this report "potentially undermine police force morale and mislead the public." He added, "When HMIC have already made their subsequent inspection it frankly seems incompetent, to say the least, to still publish a report that's seven months out of date." HMIC confirmed it had conducted a further assessment in March and would be returning in May and July.

Their packed day of public engagements began with a visit to the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. This UNESCO World Heritage Site features approximately 40,000 large black basalt columns emerging from the sea. It marked the Royal couple's inaugural visit to Northern Ireland's most famous tourist spot. The causeway originated when molten rock ascended through earth fissures, creating a lava plateau. Next, the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh proceeded to the nearby village of Bushmills to honor local soldier Robert Quigg. He received a Victoria Cross for his bravery during the Battle of the Somme. Sgt Quigg earned the highest military award for valor by entering the line of fire to find his commanding officer. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh unveiled both a statue of the soldier and a commemorative stone. His grandnephew, Leonard Quigg, also delivered a brief speech. Following this, the Royal couple attended a reception at Portrush Golf Club, hosted by the mayor for the Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council. Subsequently, they embarked on a journey through time via a steam train from Coleraine, County Londonderry, to Bellarena village. Large crowds in Coleraine greeted the couple as they boarded the 1932-built, five-carriage train. Local schoolchildren accompanied the Royal guests on their trip to Bellarena, where the Queen formally opened the village's new train station. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh had previously made this same journey along the historic Coleraine to Londonderry railway line in 1953, the year of her coronation. The original station had opened a century prior, in 1853. Earlier this year, two new railway platforms commenced operation in Bellarena, as part of a £46m upgrade to the Coleraine to Londonderry railway line. Upon her arrival in the village, the Queen unveiled a plaque commemorating this new development. Well-wishers lined the route, waving Union Flags and cheering. On Monday, the Royal visitor met Northern Ireland's first and deputy first ministers at Hillsborough Castle in County Down. This trip represents the third high-profile royal visit to Northern Ireland in recent weeks, following appearances by the Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall, and then the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh last visited Northern Ireland in June 2014.

The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) reported that London's most disadvantaged children achieved better results than those in the North. Its survey further found that five northern city-regions combined had almost as many well-qualified individuals (3.6 million) as London (3.7 million), though the IPPR predicts an increased demand for skilled workers in the North. The IPPR has proposed 11 benchmarks for Chancellor George Osborne's key policy to boost regional economies, including addressing the "stark" disparity in the development of children under five. IPPR's director Ed Cox commented: "We will never become a powerhouse economy when our children and young people have such a poor start in life. It will take a generation of investment - not only in new railways and motorways, but in the 'human capital' of the north - in education and training, starting with the youngest. If the Northern Powerhouse is to be successful, economic powers must be devolved to all corners of the North to allow businesses and policymakers to develop an economy that supports more productive, resilient and sustainable growth: jobs that pay well, prosperity that is shared, and opportunities for all." The Department for Education affirmed its commitment to ensuring every child, regardless of background, could reach their full potential. It highlighted that reforms had led to 250,000 more pupils attending good or outstanding schools in the North since 2010.

The launch of what was intended to be its leading device has devolved into a major crisis for the globe's foremost smartphone manufacturer. As the South Korean corporation works to manage the situation, we review the chronology of events:

August 2: Samsung introduced its new flagship, the Galaxy Note 7, to significant acclaim in New York. The device boasted innovative features such as an iris scanner, generating positive initial feedback and high anticipation, positioning it as a key competitor to the forthcoming iPhone 7.
August 19: Sales commenced in ten markets, including South Korea and the United States, with European markets slated for an October launch.
August 24: The first news report emerged of a Note 7 unit "exploding." Soon after, multiple similar incidents surfaced, with users uploading photos and videos purportedly showing their phones overheating, igniting, or exploding.
September 2: Samsung declared a voluntary global recall affecting approximately 2.5 million Note 7 handsets, attributing the issue to defective batteries. The company offered customers either a refund or a device replacement.
September 8: The US Federal Aviation Administration, along with numerous airlines worldwide, instructed passengers not to power on or charge the Note 7 while aboard aircraft.
September 9: The US Consumer Product Safety Commission advised people to cease using the phone, issuing a formal recall on September 15. Concurrently, Samsung announced its intention to resume Note 7 sales in South Korea on September 28.
September 19: Reports also surfaced of phones catching fire in China, though Samsung asserted that batteries in devices sold there came from a different supplier and were not impacted by the recall.
October 1: Samsung restarted Note 7 sales in South Korea. In the US, the replacement program for existing phones was actively underway.
October 6: A report emerged detailing the first instance of a replacement Note 7 exhibiting the same problems. A device on a Southwest Airlines flight in the US began emitting smoke, leading to the plane's evacuation. In subsequent days, additional reports of replacement phones overheating and catching fire followed.
October 9: US carriers AT&T and T-Mobile stated their intention to cease issuing new Note 7 replacements and discontinue selling the device.
October 11: Samsung declared a halt to all phone sales pending an investigation into the issues. The company also instructed users to power down their devices and discontinue their use.

The Asia-Europe Meeting Summit (Asem) in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, scheduled for Friday and Saturday, marks the inaugural major multilateral diplomatic assembly since the July 12 South China Sea ruling. The tribunal found that China had infringed upon the Philippines' sovereign rights and inflicted "severe harm to the coral reef environment" through its construction of artificial islands. While the ruling is binding, the Permanent Court of Arbitration lacks enforcement authority.

Google Assistant differentiates itself slightly from competitors by being designed to foster conversations with users and respond to follow-up queries.

Tech analyst Ian Fogg at IHS Technology stated that it is a natural progression for Google to offer Google Assistant to as many smartphones as possible, as AI is fundamental to Google's strategy. He added that with the machine learning underpinning Google Assistant's AI, its intelligence will improve with greater user engagement. Initially, Assistant will be accessible to English-speaking users in the United States. English-speaking users in Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom will receive the update next, with support for other languages to follow, Google confirmed.

The election commission (Inec) hoped to announce the winner Monday. The UN praised the poll, despite technical issues, protests, and Boko Haram-linked violence. Voting extended a second day in parts of Nigeria due to new electronic card reader problems. President Jonathan, among others, couldn't use the anti-fraud technology, prompting his Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which had opposed the readers, to call it a "huge national embarrassment." Inec chair Attahiru Jega, however, stressed that only a fraction of 150,000 deployed readers failed. The vote was delayed six weeks by the Boko Haram insurgency. Islamists attacked northeastern polling stations, and a curfew was declared in Bauchi State after clashes with security forces. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon lauded Nigerian voters' "determination and resilience" despite reported attacks, calling the voting "largely peaceful and orderly." The regional bloc Ecowas echoed his remarks, urging acceptance of results. Tension, however, flared in southern Rivers State as thousands protested alleged killings of opposition workers and voting irregularities. Inec was "concerned," noting one of its offices was torched during the unrest. While results were expected through Sunday night, no official lead was yet indicated. The PDP has dominated Nigerian politics since 1999, but Gen Buhari's All Progressives Congress poses a serious challenge. Voters also elected House of Representatives and Senate members.

Geoffrey Stewart, 74, from Dumfries, was one of three men in their sixties and seventies who went missing in the Southern Uplands last Tuesday. Police confirmed his death late Wednesday night at Dumfries and Galloway Royal Infirmary. George Crosbie, 73, also of Dumfries, had died earlier on Wednesday. The third man, Bobby Thomson, 64, is still receiving hospital care. Mr Stewart’s family released a statement saying: "Our family extends our love and thoughts to all families involved during this deeply sad and tragic time. We express sincere gratitude and appreciation to all services engaged in the rescue efforts and the hospital staff at Dumfries and Galloway Royal Infirmary."

The men failed to return from a hike in the Durisdeer hills on Tuesday. Sixteen members of the Moffat Mountain Rescue team (MRT), accompanied by two search and rescue dogs, combed the hills for the men until the early hours of Wednesday. The search was then halted due to heavy rain, snow, high winds, and poor visibility. When the operation recommenced at 08:30 on Wednesday, over 50 individuals, including personnel from neighbouring mountain rescue teams and a Coastguard helicopter, were involved. The men were discovered that afternoon and transported by helicopter to the hospital in Dumfries. Police stated that Mr Crosbie passed away soon after, and his walking partners were treated for hypothermia. Colin Golphin, the Moffat MRT leader, commented: "The weather, although fine during the day, worsened rapidly overnight. The team searched the hills throughout the night in extremely difficult conditions. Our condolences are with the families of the walkers who died." The experienced walkers were known to visit the Lowther Hills frequently and were familiar with the locality.

Unemployment decreased by 2,000 from the prior quarter, reaching 1.69 million between January and March, while the jobless rate held at 5.1%, according to the ONS. The number of people employed rose by 44,000 from the previous quarter to 31.58 million, pushing the employment rate to a new high of 74.2%. However, job vacancies declined by 18,000 to 745,000, marking the first fall in almost a year, the ONS reported. David Freeman, an ONS senior statistician, noted that while the employment rate hit another record, the modest increase and stable unemployment suggest a potential cooling in the job market. Average earnings, including bonuses, increased by 2% year-on-year, up from 1.9% in the three months to February, with the ONS attributing this to the timing of bonuses. Excluding bonuses, earnings growth slowed to 2.1% year-on-year in the three months to March, down from 2.2% in the three months to February. The number of jobless benefit claimants fell by 2,400 in April to 737,800, though revised data indicated a significant rise of 14,700 between February and March, the largest since autumn 2011. Stephen Crabb, the Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, hailed these as "record-breaking figures," citing more people in work than ever and the lowest unemployment rate in a decade. Conversely, economists were less optimistic. David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce, stated that despite the record employment rate, the overall economic indicators, including manufacturing, trade, and GDP, suggest a "softening in economic activity." Paul Hollingsworth, UK economist at Capital Economics, commented that while there were positive aspects, the figures generally indicated that the economic slowdown has diminished the recent strength of the jobs recovery. Martin Beck, senior economic adviser to the EY Item Club, added that with the unemployment rate returning to its pre-crisis average, expecting the rapid drops in unemployment seen in 2015 to persist indefinitely would be unrealistic.

The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, which translates to "fuel shortage in a film," became France's leading Twitter trend on Tuesday, generating over 5,000 tweets. A strike concerning new labour laws is presently impacting all eight of France's oil refineries. Approximately 20% of petrol stations are estimated to have either run out of fuel or have critically low reserves. In their online posts, French social media users referenced films such as *Total Recall*, the title of both a 1990 and 2012 science fiction movie. Notably, "Total" is also the name of a French multinational oil and gas corporation. Some users creatively modified film titles to reflect the scarcity: *Pulp Fiction* was re-imagined as *Pump Friction*, *The Full Monty* became *The Fuel Monty*, and *Mad Max: Fury Road* was replaced with *Mad Max: Fury Bicycle Lane*. American actor Vin Diesel's surname and his Hollywood blockbusters drew particular interest, inspiring several new titles for his *Fast and Furious* series, including *Last and Furious*, *Pas Fast Mais Furious* (meaning: Not Fast But Furious), *Immobile and Furious*, and *Fuel Furious*. Others renamed *8 Mile*, a semi-biographical drama starring US rapper Eminem, as *0 Mile* and *8 Miles a Pied* (translation: 8 Miles on Foot). American director Stanley Kubrick also seemed to inspire posts about *Fuel Metal Jacket*, referencing his 1987 film *Full Metal Jacket*. *2001, l'Odyssee de l'espace* is the French title for Stanley Kubrick's *2001: A Space Odyssey*, with "Espace" also being the name of a minivan produced by French car manufacturer Renault. Images of individuals filling jerrycans at petrol stations led to the term being incorporated into film titles like *Tom and Jerrrycan*, *Jerrycan Beauty*, and *Catch Me If You Jerrycan*. Nicolas Winding Refn's 2011 film *Drive* was another obvious target, with social media users altering its title to *Walk and Drive Pas*.

Immigration Minister Peter Dutton revealed that a 17-year-old was apprehended at Sydney airport two weeks prior. Mr. Dutton highlighted a "growing threat" from Australians attempting to join groups such as Islamic State (IS). Special anti-terror teams had been deployed to Australia's eight international airports in August. The teenager, who was en route to the conflict in the Middle East, was returned to his parents' care as investigations continued, according to Mr. Dutton. This interception occurred approximately a week after two Sydney brothers, aged 16 and 17, were stopped at the same airport on suspicion of trying to join IS. The brothers, whose identities remain undisclosed, were also returned to their parents. Australian media reports indicate that both students have since been permitted to resume their education at a prominent Sydney high school, despite objections raised by some parents of other students there.

'Trophy paraded online'
Australia's anti-terrorism units have engaged with 85,000 individuals at airports nationwide since August, Mr. Dutton stated. Australia estimates that around 90 of its citizens have already traveled to Iraq or Syria to fight with IS, and 20 have died in the conflict. Unconfirmed reports suggest Melbourne teenager Jake Bilardi carried out a suicide attack in Syria earlier this month after joining IS. His father, John Bilardi, told Australia's 60 Minutes that his son was a "loner" with a "death wish" and had been exploited as a "prize" by IS. Mr. Bilardi said, "He was a trophy that they paraded online. They gloated about how they had recruited this young boy who didn't even have a Muslim background." In Australia, it is a criminal offense for citizens to enter the IS strongholds of Mosul and Raqqa without a legitimate reason, such as visiting family. Any Australian traveling to these cities could face a 10-year prison sentence.

The proposed amnesty covers offenses committed during the political upheaval following Mr. Thaksin's removal by a coup. The controversial legislation cleared the lower house in the early hours of Friday and now proceeds to the Senate. The opposition Democrat Party, which abstained from the 310-0 vote, cautioned that the bill's enactment would incite street demonstrations. Jonathan Head, BBC South East Asia correspondent, reports that the bill's journey through the Senate is less assured, given that half its members are appointed. Nevertheless, it could advance as early as next week, likely sparking additional protests.

Supporters of the bill contend it will provide closure to the political instability stemming from the 2006 military coup that unseated Mr. Thaksin, which left Thailand deeply polarized. This unrest encompassed the 2008 occupation of Bangkok's primary airport and the subsequent two-month street protests in 2010, which resulted in approximately 90 deaths, predominantly civilian demonstrators. Conversely, opponents argue the amnesty would permit human rights violations to escape accountability. According to Brad Adams, Human Rights Watch's Asia director, on October 21, "The proposed amnesty would allow officials and protest leaders who have blood on their hands to go unpunished." He added, "By whitewashing past abuses, the government denies justice to victims and tells future abusers they have little to fear."

The opposition suspects the bill's true intention is to pave the way for Mr. Thaksin's return without him serving a prison term. Thaksin Shinawatra has resided in self-imposed exile abroad since his 2008 corruption conviction, which he maintains was politically motivated. Initially restricted to ordinary protesters involved in past street clashes, the amnesty was abruptly broadened two weeks ago to cover anyone investigated by post-2006 coup-established agencies. Our correspondent notes that Mr. Thaksin's conviction stemmed from one such investigation. Despite the coup, Mr. Thaksin retained popularity among rural voters, with parties aligned with him winning both general elections held since. His sister, Yingluck Shinawatra, currently serves as prime minister.

The opposition pledges to challenge the legislation. Democrat Party spokesman Chavanond Intarakomalyasut stated, "We will continue our fighting in the street until the bill is aborted. There are other avenues such as by petitioning the Constitutional Court." On Thursday, while the bill was under debate, thousands gathered in protest outside a railway station.

Over the next few years, Forest Enterprise Scotland will plant them around Loch Trool and the Cree Valley. It is anticipated that these acorns will help cultivate about 600,000 young trees, thereby creating a "large and vibrant habitat." Environment forester Gareth Ventress mentioned that as soon as they realized they were in for a "bumper crop" of acorns, they began formulating collection plans. He noted, "We also decided to seek assistance from other staff across Scotland and requested them to gather acorns from other native oak woods located on the national forest estate." The Cree Valley Community Woodland Trust, Borders Forest Trust, and Moffat Community Woodlands all supported this large-scale collection effort to promote native woodland expansion across their project areas in south Scotland. By combining acorns collected from various locations within Galloway Forest Park, the genetic diversity of the trees connecting the remnant woodlands is enhanced. This is crucial for establishing robust and resilient woodlands capable of effectively managing pests and diseases far into the future. The acorns are collected by spreading large felt nets across the forest floor, which prevents them from touching the soil and simplifies the gathering process. Once collected, the acorns are sorted and subsequently stored. Over the next three to four years, the acorn seeds will be germinated and nurtured so that saplings can then be planted, though many seeds will be "graded" out and considered infertile during this period. Approximately 600,000 saplings are projected to be produced from these acorns. These young trees will contribute to the formation of new oak woods and "enrich the woodland habitats" throughout Galloway Forest Park.

Mr Carney stated that long-term financing of green projects in emerging markets would foster financial stability. Speaking at an event in Berlin, he pressed Germany to utilize its 2017 G20 presidency to advance this agenda. Carney had previously highlighted the dangers climate change poses to the financial sector. At the Thursday event, Mr Carney noted that, theoretically, capital ought to flow from advanced to emerging economies due to higher returns. However, he observed that in practice, the opposite has transpired, leading to suppressed bond yields in advanced economies. He added that intermittent capital flows to emerging economies have proven destabilizing. "In this context, green finance presents a major opportunity. By ensuring that capital flows finance long-term projects in countries where growth is most carbon intensive, financial stability can be promoted," he asserted. Mr Carney projected that green bond issuance – for example, to help finance water or renewable power projects designed to reduce carbon emissions – could double in 2016 from last year's $42 billion. Yet, he pointed out that these still constitute merely 1% of assets held by global financial institutions. "The development of this new global asset class offers a chance to advance a low carbon future while boosting worldwide investment and stimulating growth," he remarked. He elaborated on a paradox: that by the time a clear economic incentive to act against climate change emerges, it will be too late for effective action. A further potential issue he highlighted was that "an excessively swift transition to a low-carbon economy might significantly impair financial stability." As part of the shift towards a low-carbon economy, Mr Carney also urged companies to disclose the financial risks climate change presents to their business models. He had previously warned the finance industry about climate change risks, including the prospect that most fossil fuel reserves could become unburnable as governments strive to curb global warming.

The Conservative party's election manifesto indicated that a funding floor would only be implemented after a referendum was called. The St David's Day Agreement had previously described the vote as an "expectation," yet Labour Welsh ministers oppose a referendum preceding a funding deal. Labour accused the Tories of attempting to pressure them. The manifesto stated the Conservatives would "introduce a 'funding floor' to protect Welsh relative funding and provide certainty for the Welsh Government to plan for the future, once it has called a referendum on Income Tax powers in the next Parliament." However, a Welsh Conservative spokeswoman clarified to BBC Wales: "The St David's Day commitment we made to introduce a funding floor for Wales is firm and clear, and work is already underway at the Treasury and the Wales Office to bring this floor forward. The funding floor for Wales is not contingent on an income tax referendum. Our UK manifesto makes clear our expectation that the Welsh Assembly will hold a referendum on income tax raising powers early in the next Parliament. More detail of our ambitious plan for Wales will be announced in the Conservative Party Welsh Manifesto which will be launched later this week." On Friday, Chancellor George Osborne informed BBC Wales that the funding floor would range between £113 and £116 per head for every £100 spent in England, a range recommended by economist Gerry Holtham. Labour has also committed to introducing a funding floor for the Welsh government but has not specified a figure. Reacting to the Conservative manifesto, First Minister Carwyn Jones asserted: "A vote for the Tories is a vote for a government that would cost Wales up to £300m a year. A fair funding settlement is either fair or it isn't - you can't impose conditions or try and hold the government over a barrel." The Liberal Democrats pledged to commission an independent review of Wales' funding arrangements, aiming to increase the Welsh government's budget. Plaid Cymru advocated for an additional £1.2bn annually for the Welsh government, claiming this would align spending with Scottish levels. UKIP expressed a desire to abolish the existing Barnett formula, which dictates funding for the four UK nations.

Hibs suffered a significant 10-1 aggregate defeat against Bayern Munich, while City lost 3-1 to Sweden's Eskilstuna United. Signeul expressed her delight to BBC Scotland, calling it "fantastic for Scottish football" to have two teams in the Champions League, which she attributed to their previous achievements in securing these two spots. She highlighted that the Netherlands, set to host the Euro 2017 finals and play Scotland in an October 20 friendly in Livingston, fields only one team in Europe's top club competition. This allocation, she clarified, is entirely "based on rankings and what Glasgow City and the national team have done previously."

Making their debut in the knockout stage, Hibs faced a formidable opponent. Signeul described it as "a great experience for this young Hibs team," despite an "unlucky" draw against Bayern Munich, whom she identified as a likely title contender. Bayern's squad boasted 26 full-time professionals, all representing national teams from Austria, Switzerland, Germany, and the Netherlands, and included the Olympic tournament's golden boot winner, making them "a tough side." She emphasized the importance for Hibs players to recognize this as the benchmark level, warning against the false sense of superiority that can arise from playing weaker international teams.

City, nine-time consecutive Scottish champions, reached the Champions League quarter-finals in 2014 but have faced round of 32 elimination for the past two seasons. Signeul noted that "Glasgow City had a chance in their game," but conceded that Eskilstuna, the Swedish runners-up, proved "a little too strong," adding that City experienced some misfortune with how goals were conceded in both matches.

Meanwhile, the position of Signeul's Scottish FA colleague, men's head coach Gordon Strachan, was questioned this week following a draw with Lithuania and a defeat by Slovakia in their 2018 World Cup qualifiers. Signeul contended that drawing parallels between her side's success and Strachan's was unfair, explaining that "results usually follow the rankings in women's football," whereas the men's game is more competitive and less predictable. She further stated her belief that Strachan, who has opted to remain in his role, continues to receive the full support of his players.

The concept of future transport leans towards hiring vehicles rather than personal ownership of cars and bikes. This week, London saw a prime example with the launch of oBike, a company backed by substantial venture capital, introducing hundreds of hire bikes onto the city's streets. Having already run extensive operations in South East Asia, oBike aims to have thousands in the capital by the end of the summer. A key difference from existing cycle hire schemes is that oBike's bikes are dockless; a locking rear brake means they can be left anywhere. Users access them via an app and locate them using a GPS tracker. The service requires a one-off £49 refundable deposit, followed by a charge of 50p per half-hour. Other companies are expected to follow suit.

oBike states its goal is to work in conjunction with existing schemes, pursuing a social agenda to help clean up London's air and reduce emissions. It also seeks collaboration with Transport for London (TfL) and local councils, though this has not yet materialized. Some councils are incensed that they were not consulted, with bikes reportedly "dumped" in their areas without warning. Hackney Council, while generally supportive of cycle hire, voiced concerns that oBike's unrestricted parking could obstruct pavements and roads, adding that it has had no dialogue with the company at all. In Hammersmith & Fulham, the west London council raised concerns with oBike when approximately 400 of its yellow bikes appeared in the borough unannounced. Cllr Stephen Cowan, leader of Hammersmith & Fulham Council, stated, "We're very much in favour of cycling, but we expect companies to properly consult with us first. This launch could have been much better thought out." He confirmed that oBike has agreed to remove the bikes it deposited in the borough.

As has been seen before in London, this situation highlights a clash between authorities and new technology companies. City Hall has offered a rather guarded welcome. London's Walking and Cycling Commissioner, Will Norman, commented that dockless bike operators must collaborate with TfL and borough councils to guarantee these bikes serve all Londoners without adversely affecting other cyclists, road users, or pedestrians. He added that while such schemes offer genuine potential to broaden cycling accessibility, their implementation must be suitable for the capital.

The Confederation of African Football's Executive Committee named Gabon as host on Wednesday, surpassing rival bids from Ghana and Algeria. "We will prepare ourselves to win the Nations Cup in 2017," declared Gabon football official Jean-Felix Mba Nze. "We have decided to play and win the cup." Gabon initially entered the Nations Cup in 1970 but did not qualify for the finals until 1994. Their best performances saw them reach the quarter-finals in 1996 and 2012, the latter being a tournament they co-hosted with Equatorial Guinea. During this year's Nations Cup, also held in Equatorial Guinea, the Panthers exited early after securing one victory and two defeats in their group stage matches. The 2017 Nations Cup will mark the first time Gabon has independently hosted the finals. Mba Nze, the secretary general of the Gabonese federation, told BBC Sport that their main objective is "to organise a better competition than we did in 2012." He added, "I think we won the bid because we made a good presentation and we have made efforts to improve all the stadiums, hospitals and media facilities. We are more developed than we were for the last Nations Cup." Gabon plans to use two stadiums from the 2012 finals – in Libreville (45,000 capacity) and Franceville (25,000) – and will construct two additional venues. The new 20,000-seater stadiums in Port Gentil and Oyem are expected to be ready by August 2016, five months ahead of the competition. Gabon's success was met with resentment by the countries it defeated. The Algerian press criticized the decision, with Algeria Soir calling it a "sporting and political defeat for Algeria," while El Watan regretted that the country's presentation lacked "sufficient political support." Meanwhile, the Ghanaian bid informed the BBC it was "intrigued" by the decision, demanding greater transparency in the results process and questioning why the Confederation of African Football (CAF) had not released the results publicly. In response, CAF stated that voting results were similarly not disclosed when the host nations for the 2019, 2021, and 2023 Nations Cups were announced last September.

Primarily male, these "superfans" also exhibit a greater propensity than average consumers to purchase music in CD format or via digital downloads. This data was gathered from a survey involving 504 UK residents, each of whom had participated in at least one festival within the past year. Eventbrite, the ticketing website that commissioned the survey, states that these "superfans" significantly "drive the music festivals market" by frequently recommending music and events to their social circles. They constitute 28% of the festival attendees, and over half (54%) express a willingness to go to an event solo. These fans spend, on average, £45 more per event compared to casual attendees; however, their loyalty isn't assured, with 46% feeling that festivals are becoming "excessively corporate." Annually, over 100 music festivals occur across the UK, ranging from major events like Glastonbury and T In The Park to more intimate gatherings such as the Cambridge Jazz Festival and Jamie Oliver's Big Feastival. According to Music UK, a total of 3.7 million individuals attend festivals annually, supporting over 39,000 full-time employment positions. Nevertheless, narrow profit margins and market saturation have led to difficulties for some events. For instance, 57 festivals, including Oxegen and The Big Chill, were compelled to cancel in the rainy summer of 2012. While the pace of cancellations has decreased subsequently, several events this year—such as Bristol's Temples festival, Sedgefield's Down To The Woods, and Tunbridge Wells' Field Day—were called off; additionally, Sonisphere did not resume after its planned break in 2015. Despite these challenges, recent research provides a degree of comfort for organisers, as 88% of survey participants indicated intentions to attend a festival next year, with over half planning to attend multiple. Paul Reed, who directs the Association of Independent Festivals, noted, "This has been a tough year for certain festivals, marked by adverse weather, post-Brexit economic ambiguity, increased costs, and elevated security worries." He added, "This study demonstrates the sector's continued vibrancy, the resilience of festival promoters, and their ongoing commitment to creating memorable experiences for audiences eager to revisit their preferred events annually." Cromer recorded 37 crimes over the weekend, including the rape of a teenager, which residents connected to a group of travelers. Suffolk Constabulary stated it had warned Norfolk Police about the group before its Friday arrival. Norfolk confirmed receiving this alert and said it was reviewing its response. Suffolk officers explained they notified their Norfolk colleagues after the group was served a local authority notice to leave Lowestoft on Friday afternoon. This notice followed several disturbance incidents in that town. Norfolk acknowledged the information but stated there was "no intelligence to suggest where the group was heading." On Friday, a woman in her late teens was raped at a bus stop on Cadogan Road, near the seafront. Norfolk Police indicated evidence suggested a possible link to the town's disorder. One man was arrested and later released under investigation in connection with the rape, with no other arrests made. On Saturday night, a BBC reporter was told by a taxi driver that "travellers are rampaging the town," and staff at The Wellington pub reported closing after a group of 30 travelers became "rowdy." Lee Sale, who runs a local ice cream shop, said travelers had frightened families with "intimidating behaviour." Ayrun Nessa, wife of the Masala Twist restaurant owner, recounted being confronted at the door by six women shouting abuse. Cromer's Safer Neighbourhood Team is holding police surgeries, providing residents a chance to raise concerns with officers. Up to 25 travelers' caravans arrived at the town's Runton Road cliff-top car park on Friday, but have since moved on.

The A320 pilot reported observing a white quadcopter drone "flash past" the aircraft in August of the previous year, while flying south of Brookmans Park. A UK Airprox Board report stated that no avoiding action was possible due to the lack of available time, concluding that a "collision had only been narrowly avoided and chance had played a major part." Air traffic control relayed the A320 pilot's report of "something having just gone over the top of him" at approximately 18:45 BST on August 15, 2016, during a flight north of Potters Bar. Although the controller mentioned another aircraft had recently crossed above, the pilot described the object as red and white, with red and blue stripes on two of its rotor arms, and less than a meter in size. All drone operators are mandated to comply with Air Navigation Order (ANO) 2016 articles, which require anyone in charge of a small unmanned aircraft to only fly it if reasonably confident the flight can be safely made, and not to recklessly or negligently cause or permit the aircraft to endanger any person or property. They must also maintain "direct, unaided visual contact" with the aircraft, sufficient to monitor its flight path in relation to other aircraft. Airprox board members concurred that the drone had been operated at an altitude beyond direct unaided line-of-sight, which is prohibited under current regulations without explicit Civil Aviation Authority permission, thereby creating a conflict with the A320. The drone operator could not be identified.

A study of employees and managers found that a quarter of new fathers took no paternity leave at all, and fewer than one in 10 extended their leave beyond the two weeks legally mandated. Research by the Institute of Leadership & Management (ILM) attributed this to deeply ingrained employer attitudes and new fathers' financial concerns about taking time off. Last year, the government announced plans to allow parents to share their maternity and paternity leave, with changes set to begin in April 2015. However, the ILM's research suggested these reforms would have little impact unless employer attitudes were also addressed.

Charles Elvin, ILM chief executive, stated, "The introduction of shared parental leave is a crucial step towards enabling more women to progress into senior roles." He added, "Yet our research revealed cultural barriers are impeding the uptake of both two weeks statutory paternity leave and additional paternity leave." He noted a persistent "cultural expectation" within organisations that women, rather than men, will be the ones taking extended periods away from the workplace. The report also indicated that low levels of paternity pay discouraged new fathers, with only 9% surveyed receiving more than two weeks on full pay.

Responding to the report, Frances O'Grady, secretary general of the TUC, the trade union body, identified pay as the major concern. "Many dads simply can't afford to take time off, particularly as employers rarely top up their statutory pay." Currently, employed fathers are entitled to either one or two weeks' paid paternity leave, though additional leave is also granted if the mother returns to work and is not claiming statutory maternity pay. Government plans involve extending this flexibility, allowing parents of newborns to exchange and share their leave.

A government spokesperson stated, "We want the introduction of shared parental leave to drive a real cultural shift and help working dads play a greater role in their child's early months." They added, "Employers too can gain from a system which allows them to keep talented women in the workforce and have more motivated and productive staff."

Similar to last year's event, only Orangemen and their 13 officially registered bands are permitted to process past St Patrick's Church on Donegall Street in north Belfast. Their passage must be accompanied by the sound of a single drum beat. For this year, all musical performances must cease 43 metres from the church, ensuring no music can be heard within its proximity. Additionally, a planned protest by residents has been limited to a maximum of 50 participants across two designated sites. The Orange Order expressed its dismay at the ruling. They stated the commission has become merely a vehicle for republican propaganda, enabling republicans to dictate the conditions for loyal order parades regarding their timing, manner, and location. They further argued that the newly fabricated criterion of prohibiting music within "earshot" of a disused place of worship is both malicious and preposterous, clearly designed to further suppress Protestant heritage on what are supposedly shared streets in Northern Ireland's capital. He added, "The document clearly indicates that the Parades Commission seriously considered prohibiting music outside Clifton Street Orange hall. I wish that assertion were a jest, but it is not." The 34-year-old midfielder recently concluded his stint in the Indian Super League with Atletico Kolkata. "Having been a player who's come back three times, I understand the draw and the desire to return," stated McFadden, who confirmed Motherwell has extended an offer to him. "And I know Pearo feels precisely the same." Pearson started his professional journey at Fir Park, and following periods at Celtic, Derby County, Bristol City, and Karela Blasters, he returned to Motherwell for a single season in 2015. He is currently a free agent, having contributed to Kolkata's fourth-place league finish in India and subsequently securing the title through a play-off triumph against his former team, Karela. "We've had discussions with him and presented an offer; we're now awaiting his response," McFadden confirmed, noting Motherwell's history of re-embracing former players. "Pearo would be a fantastic asset both on and off the pitch here. We're keen to have him return, so we hope he makes the correct choice and comes back. I know he has a few considerations before deciding, but he is aware that everyone here would welcome him back wholeheartedly." In recent days, Motherwell has secured winger Elliot Frear from Forest Green, in addition to bringing in Reading defender Zak Jules and Everton goalkeeper Russell Griffiths on loan. Nevertheless, the club is still seeking to bolster its squad before the closure of the transfer window. "It's a possibility; we're continuing to work on that," McFadden added. "However, we haven't received replies from those we're in discussions with, so we'll have to wait and see."

Kevin Mcleod, 24, was discovered deceased in Wick harbour in February 1997. Although his death was officially ruled accidental, his family contends that injuries on his body indicate he was murdered. Following discussions between his family and Chief Constable Phil Gormley, an evaluation was conducted of "all known information" concerning the death. Police stated this review involved locating and interviewing individuals who were in Wick the night Mr. Mcleod died but had not previously come forward. Last month, Mr. Mcleod's mother, June, informed BBC Scotland that if the assessment "yielded nothing new," she and her family would persist in their demand for a new investigation. Separately, the chief constable has commissioned an assessment into how police handled the Mcleod family's complaints regarding the death investigation since 1997. Detective Chief Superintendent Gareth Blair, head of major crime at Police Scotland, explained the assessment was performed "in recognition of the continued impact" of Mr. Mcleod's death on his parents and "their desire for a conclusive outcome." He conveyed, "Our sympathies remain with them." He emphasized, "It is important to stress, this was not a full reinvestigation of the death itself, but a careful and considered analysis of a significant volume of information which has been recorded relating to the circumstances since 1997." He added that "Specialist officers from Police Scotland's major crime command undertook this work, which included tracing and speaking to individuals who were in Wick that night and saw Kevin but who had not previously come forward." Det Ch Supt Blair confirmed he informed Mr. Mcleod's parents on Tuesday about the assessment's conclusion. He stated, "I informed Kevin's parents that having carried out this assessment there is no evidence of criminality and his death remains unexplained, leading me to determine that there is no basis on which to launch a full reinvestigation." He also issued an appeal: "Police Scotland appeals for any witnesses who have information about Kevin's death to come forward and we will fully consider any new and additional information." Furthermore, he noted, "The chief constable has asked the head of professional standards to carry out a separate assessment to ensure that all matters/complaints raised by the family over the years have been appropriately considered and addressed."

Matthew Eteson is currently facing trial at Preston Crown Court, charged with the gross negligence manslaughter of Kelly Webster, 36, and Lauren Thornton. The two victims tragically died in their sleep on a boat on Windermere in April 2013. Mr Eteson, 42, from Hale in Greater Manchester, has entered a not guilty plea to the charge. The family had traveled to the Lake District for the Easter bank holiday weekend to celebrate a friend's birthday. However, on the afternoon of April 1, Mr Eteson moved the generator from the deck and employed it to power a 1kW fan heater, aiming to warm the sleeping quarters, according to prosecutor Mr Graham Reeds QC. The court heard that there was no warning of the toxic gas accumulating because the carbon monoxide sensors had been disabled beforehand. Mr Reeds stated that the mother and daughter, both residents of Leyland in Lancashire, were discovered deceased in their sleeping positions aboard the second-hand Bayliner 285 motor cruiser, named Arniston, with lethal levels of carbon monoxide in their systems. Mr Eteson, who had been sleeping in a separate cabin further from the generator, also suffered from carbon monoxide poisoning but managed to wake up and find the bodies. It was also revealed in court that Mr Eteson, a qualified gas fitter, had modified the generator and its exhaust, alterations that experts later deemed "dangerous." Nia Webster, Ms Webster's mother, had previously inquired with Mr Eteson about the carbon monoxide sensors. He informed her they were non-functional and that his partner would disconnect a portable

NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) stressed the vital role of O negative blood, as it can be administered to patients of any blood group in emergency situations. Although only 7% of the UK population has O negative blood, it accounts for 12% of all blood transfusions. Meanwhile, B negative blood is crucial for specific ethnic groups. NHSBT noted that ethnic minority communities, who are more likely to have B negative blood, face a higher risk of sickle cell anaemia, a condition where misshapen blood cells can block vessels, potentially causing an early demise. These groups are also more susceptible to thalassemia, a set of inherited blood disorders that hinder the blood's ability to carry oxygen. Despite only 2% of Britain's population being B negative, hospitals have used 6% more of this blood type over the past four weeks compared to the same period last year, NHSBT reported. The organization explained that B negative blood is beneficial because it can be used for both B negative and B positive patients. Donna Batty, NHSBT's donor relations manager, appealed to donors to come forward "in the next few days." She stated that stock levels of "these vulnerable groups" are "lower than we would prefer." Ms. Batty added: "We also ask donors from those blood groups with upcoming appointments to keep them. We hope our fantastic donors respond to this appeal and bear with us if there are slightly longer waits than normal at sessions as a result." In total, 4% of the UK's population currently donates blood. Jon Latham, NHSBT's assistant director of marketing, indicated that they ideally seek "first-time donors." He explained: "The larger our database of willing donors, the easier it becomes to call upon them at times of the year when we need a particular group." Individuals unsure of their blood type can find out after donating, NHSBT clarified. Those interested in donating should call NHSBT on 0300 123 23 23.

Dr. Stephen Farry, the Minister for Employment and Learning, has decided to discontinue a special premium payment of Â£1.1m that the institution received as compensation for its small size and specialized status. With fewer than 1,000 students and an annual income of Â£4.7m, the college faces significant challenges. Protesters have stated that removing this small institution premium, combined with broader funding cuts from the Department of Employment and Learning (DEL), would result in the college losing 31% of its budget. However, a recently announced additional Â£32m for the DEL in this week's overall budget offers some improvement. The college now estimates that, with the extra funds, it would need to operate on a budget reduced by 26.5%. While a slightly better forecast, Principal Prof. Peter Finn asserts that this reduction remains excessively challenging. He accuses Stephen Farry of making a clearly opportunistic decision to compel the college to accept one of the solutions he proposes for streamlining teacher training in Northern Ireland. None of the four options presented would allow St Mary's to maintain its current autonomy. The college insists on preserving its unique character and Catholic ethos, though Prof. Finn expresses enthusiasm for what he terms "very deep sharing" among the various teacher training institutions. This could involve students from one institution occasionally receiving instruction at other university colleges. Prof. Finn strongly refutes the idea that small-scale and specialist premia are exclusive to Northern Ireland and thus should be abolished. He acknowledges that similar payments were removed from institutions in England, but notes that those bodies were subsequently permitted to charge much higher tuition fees and faced no restrictions on student intake, freedoms not granted to St Mary's. Stranmillis University College, which primarily trains teachers for non-Catholic schools, faces comparable difficulties and has been in negotiations since 2008 to merge entirely with Queen's University. This merger process has encountered opposition and is not yet approved. Both the funding reduction and the removal of the premia would also impact Stranmillis.

The investment benefits from nearly £15 million from the Welsh government, with production scheduled to commence in late 2018. Economy Minister Edwina Hart stated the agreement would "safeguard more than 750 skilled Welsh jobs for many years," adding, "In a climate of stiff global competitiveness, we have been actively seeking to win a share of this investment for Wales." She further remarked, "Ford's decision to manufacture its new innovative engine here in Wales is a tribute to the reputation of the local management team and the quality and loyalty of the Welsh workforce." The Ford Bridgend plant, established in 1980, has historically triumphed over intense competition to secure over £2.8 billion in successive investments. Ford indicates its operations support approximately 10,000 jobs in South Wales, with 1,860 individuals employed at the plant itself. Technicians from Essex and Germany collaborated on the design and development of the new fuel-efficient engine range. A Ford letter to workers, seen by the BBC in June, suggested that winning the investment necessitated changes to working conditions at Bridgend to enhance the plant's competitiveness. Welsh Conservative shadow economy minister William Graham interpreted Friday's announcement as a sign of "confidence in the UK government's efforts to rebuild the economy." This offers positive news for Bridgend employees, as new production will begin in 2018, just as Jaguar Land Rover engine manufacturing at the site concludes, thereby securing hundreds of jobs that might otherwise have been jeopardized. This year, 200 fixed-contract workers were laid off at Ford Bridgend after it ceased manufacturing engines for Volvo. Concerns persist, however, that the new investment might limit Bridgend to producing only one-third of its current engine volume. Some question the Welsh government's £15 million contribution to a multinational company's investment in its own facility. Bridgend was in contention with three other European Ford plants for this contract, all receiving standard governmental financial support. The global automotive industry is exceptionally competitive, making government backing crucial to prevent companies from seeking opportunities elsewhere.

S4C primarily derives its funding from the licence fee, and UK ministers have announced a comprehensive review of the BBC. Monmouth MP David Davies informed BBC Wales that S4C constitutes a "special case as it promotes the Welsh language." Ministers have indicated that S4C should aim for similar cost efficiencies as the BBC. On Thursday, Labour warned that reductions to the BBC's budget posed a threat to S4C, but Culture Secretary John Whittingdale assured MPs of a commitment to the channel "within the next couple of years," expressing his hope for discussions with its management soon. Mr. Davies told BBC Radio Cymru's Rhaglen Dylan Jones on Friday that "the government recognises S4C's importance and that it's more than just a station; it's vital for the future of the Welsh language." Mr. Davies also implied that the Welsh Affairs Committee, which he chairs, might consider initiating an inquiry into broadcasting, encompassing S4C. He further stated: "These are personal views, but I believe S4C to be a special case as it promotes the Welsh language, and I consider it more important that S4C continues than any other BBC channel." S4C has reported "substantial cuts" since 2010 and plans to highlight the "uniqueness" of its service, along with its "value and importance, both culturally and economically," during discussions with ministers. A green paper on the BBC's future, released Thursday, observed that "audience reach has been declining across some indigenous language services over the last few years, particularly in Wales." It also added that the higher hourly cost of Welsh-language radio programming compared to English-language output "raises concerns about value for money."

The latest Markit Report on Jobs for Scotland indicated substantial increases in permanent and temporary job placements during April. Demand for temporary staff also reached its highest point in nearly a decade. However, recruiters cautioned that this success was jeopardized by decreasing candidate availability, as employers struggled to acquire the necessary skills. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) urged that the party forming a government after the June 8 general election must secure access to essential international workers and invest in UK jobseekers.

The jobs report revealed that permanent appointments grew for the third consecutive month in April, expanding at the fastest rate in 21 months. This contrasted with a general slowdown observed across the UK. Temporary placements also saw a sharp rise, the steepest since August 2014. Conversely, the availability of workers declined further in April, with permanent staff availability experiencing its most significant drop in nine months. Meanwhile, Scottish temporary candidate availability fell at the quickest pace in almost two years. The IT and computing, nursing/medical/care, and hotel and catering sectors recorded the highest growth in demand for permanent staff, while nursing/medical/care, IT and computing, and engineering and construction led the demand for temporary staff. The report also found that average salaries for new permanent employees in Scotland rose sharply in April, and the rate of temporary pay increases in Scotland was the fastest recorded in a year.

REC chief executive Kevin Green stated: "The resurgence of the Scottish jobs market persists for the third consecutive month. Demand for temporary staff is at its highest in almost 10 years as employers manage Brexit uncertainty and meet consumer demand. News of increasing starting salaries for permanent roles is also welcome – there's much to be optimistic about north of the border." He added: "Declining candidate availability threatens this success because employers are struggling to secure the skills they need. If British business is to thrive, the government formed after June 8 must address the shrinking pool of suitable candidates by investing in skills and career advice for UK jobseekers, as well as safeguarding access to the workers we need from abroad. It is vital that the future immigration system is agile enough to reflect and adapt to evolving labour market needs."

Envoy Sigrid Kaag delivered her remarks as Syria reportedly failed to meet a Sunday deadline for the removal of its chemical arsenal from the country. All of Syria's chemical weapons are scheduled for destruction by June 30. The Russian-US agreement to eliminate Syria's stockpile was crafted last year, following a sarin rocket attack outside Damascus that claimed hundreds of lives. The multinational mission responsible for getting rid of these weapons is overseen jointly by the UN Security Council and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW). While the UN's ultimate deadline for the complete destruction of Syria's chemical weapons is June 30, Damascus had previously pledged to finish removing its stockpile by April 27, having already missed several earlier deadlines. Ms. Kaag, who heads the OPCW-UN Joint Mission, told the BBC that "the largest proportion of the chemical weapons material has been moved but not yet destroyed, and that contributes to the June 30 deadline. That's why it's so critical to secure the remainder of the chemical weapons material that is still in one location." She also stated that the UN was troubled by recent reports alleging Syrian forces had used chlorine gas as a weapon. Chlorine was not a substance included in the deal, an agreement widely seen as having prevented US military action against the Syrian government. Damascus has denied employing chlorine gas offensively. According to the OPCW, most of Syria's chemical weapon substances exist as separate materials that only become highly toxic warfare agents when combined. Ms. Kaag confirmed that the facilities necessary to produce, prepare, and launch a chemical weapons attack have been demolished. "What remains are the components of a chemical weapon, but Syria's chemical weapons program, as per its current declaration to the OPCW under the Chemical Weapons Convention, is no longer operational," she affirmed.

Seattle Reign's Kim Little has been named the second recipient of the BBC World Service award, having topped a supporters' poll. She bested a strong shortlist featuring Gaelle Enganamouit (FC Rosengard, Sweden), Amandine Henry (Olympique Lyonnais), Carli Lloyd (Houston Dash), and Becky Sauerbrunn (FC Kansas City). "I'm surprised to win, I'm extremely humbled to win," the 25-year-old Little commented, adding, "Women's football is in a great place. Hopefully it will progress further." Little received her award at her club's training ground on Tuesday.

Mary Hockaday, Controller of BBC World Service English, congratulated Little: "It's been another outstanding year for women's football and Kim's talent shines through on the pitch. I'm delighted BBC World Service plays an important part in giving female footballers the recognition they deserve."

In 2015, Little was Seattle's leading scorer and ranked second overall in America's National Women's Soccer League with 10 goals, helping the Reign finish top of the league. She also spent time on loan at Melbourne City that year. The former Hibernian and Arsenal Ladies star, a five-time title winner with the Gunners, boasts 115 appearances for Scotland, scoring 46 goals. The Aberdeen-born player also contributed to Great Britain reaching the quarter-finals at the London Olympics in 2012. Her individual accolades include being named the FA's Women's Player of the Year in 2010 and the inaugural recipient of the PFA Women's Players' Player of the Year award in 2013.

Scotland coach Anna Signeul praised Little's comprehensive skill set: "She's a player that has almost everything. She's quick, her balance and movement on the pitch is fantastic. She has brilliant technique, There aren't many things that she can't do. She's a role model. She's perfect in everything she does on and off the pitch and I think it will take a long time before Scotland gets another player like this."

Over half of the world's top 10 male golfers withdrew from Rio 2016, citing concerns about the Zika virus. Briton Justin Rose, among a group at four-under, achieved the first-ever Olympic hole-in-one on the par-three fourth. Rose remarked, "While luck is always a factor, this could be considered a truly excellent hole-in-one. My last one earned me a car, but this is undeniably superior, offering better bragging rights. Being the first to accomplish something means that achievement can never be taken from you. It was certainly a memorable moment." Newly crowned Open champion Henrik Stenson shares second place with Canada's Graham Delaet, both at five-under. Rose is part of a five-way tie for fourth at four-under, alongside Belgium's Thomas Pieters, France's Gregory Bourdy, Germany's Alex Cejka, and Spain's Rafael Cabrera Bello. Danny Willett, the first British Masters champion in two decades after his April victory, concluded his round at even par with a score of 71. The second round commences on Friday at 11:30 BST; however, no halfway cut will be made due to the limited Olympic field of just 60 players. In July, Northern Ireland's Rory McIlroy stated he was unlikely to watch the Olympic golf on television, preferring "track and field, swimming, diving, the stuff that matters."

A charity match between England and Scotland, organized by former England international and Northampton Saints captain Edgar Mobbs, took place on January 30, 1915, with the objective of enlisting sportsmen into Mobbs's World War One battalion. A commemorative fixture will be held on January 24, 2015, at Olney Rugby Club. This event will feature players from the East Midlands region competing against The 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment, while the Olney Ladies team will play the Army Women's XV.

Born in Northampton in 1882, Edgar Mobbs began his rugby career in Olney before becoming captain of Northampton Rugby Football Club in 1907. He earned seven caps for England after being selected in 1909, notably scoring a try on his debut against Australia. During World War One, he rose from private to battalion commander, fighting in significant engagements such as Loos, Somme, Arras, and Messines. Mobbs was twice Mentioned in Despatches and received the Distinguished Service Order. He tragically died on July 31, 1917, while leading a charge against a German machine gun during the Battle of Passchendaele.

Despite retiring from rugby at 30 in 1913, Mobbs was denied an officer's commission at the outbreak of war due to his age, leading him to enlist as a private. He was subsequently tasked with encouraging recruitment, famously addressing a large crowd at a Northampton Saints game. His efforts are credited with convincing over 200 men to join. The 1915 international match reportedly inspired hundreds to sign up for his own corps, the Sportsman's Battalion, which became a vital component of the 7th Battalion of the Northamptonshire Regiment. Tragically, 16 Olney players were among those who died during the war.

Family members of Mobbs, including his great-nephew, also named Edgar Mobbs, are expected to attend next year's game. His great-nephew quoted MP Ryland Adkins, who stated, "Northamptonshire in time of peace produced no finer sportsman and in time of war no finer soldier." Jarlath McElroy, Chairman of Olney Rugby Club, lauded Mr. Mobbs as a "sporting and war hero." Funds generated from the event will be donated to the Soldiers' and Sailors' Families Association military charity.
