Currently, the government allocates £22 million annually towards this collection. The long-term objective is for the charity to achieve financial self-sufficiency. However, other governmental responsibilities, like the listing of buildings, will continue to be publicly funded. A new official body, provisionally named the National Heritage Protection Service, will also provide advice on planning matters. The new charity will retain the name English Heritage, and the 420 sites within the National Heritage Collection – including London's Kenwood House and Charles Darwin's former residence in Kent – will remain under public ownership. Government funding for the charity is set to be gradually phased out from 2015, eventually ceasing entirely. This will afford the charity greater autonomy to generate income through commercial activities and philanthropic contributions. A portion of the £80 million provided by the government will be used to establish the charity, ensuring it is fully operational by March 2015. In an official statement, the government agency described the planned changes, which will undergo a consultation process, as "an excellent outcome." They elaborated, "This year we have been celebrating 100 years of state protection for heritage and today's announcement sets the scene for the next century. The court heard Kelly had previously worked as a support worker for Ms Beattie, who had several medical conditions, including seizures. The divorced mother and Kelly later became friends and frequently socialized together. However, the social care graduate attacked her at her home after she reportedly made "derogatory" comments about his children. Kelly grabbed Ms Beattie and choked her before leaving the apartment. Kelly also remarked: "We're just pals - I had been her support worker." Police were called, and Kelly told officers the past few days had been "torture." On April 3rd, shortly after 3:30 PM BST, a train traveling from Penzance to Exeter collided with another train positioned on platform six. Initial findings from the Rail Accident Investigation Branch indicated that the signaller believed there was sufficient space for both trains on the platform. Approximately 35 individuals sustained injuries. The report clarified that "permissive working," which allows trains to share a platform, is an authorized procedure for passenger trains utilizing platform six. From the signal box window, the signaller observed the rear of the stationary train and incorrectly estimated ample room for the approaching train to occupy the platform. According to the report, one train was diverted to platform six because passenger lifts on other platforms were out of service for maintenance. As it approached Plymouth, the train in motion accelerated to approximately 21 mph, then navigated a comparatively sharp, left-hand bend. It was at this point that the driver noticed the stationary train's rear on platform six, surprised by its close proximity to the platform's western extremity. The investigation report detailed that the driver checked the tracks to confirm the train's route and, upon realizing an impact was unavoidable, engaged the emergency brake. This action transpired roughly three seconds before the collision, which occurred at approximately 15 mph. Numerous passengers, already standing in readiness to disembark, were propelled against the train's interior fixtures and onto the floor.

Mr. Museveni's supporters asserted that his opponents offered no credible path for progress. However, Mr. Besigye, who is currently under house arrest, denounced the results as a "sham" and urged the international community to reject them. The retailer asserts that its proposed Chippenham development would generate 1,000 jobs and inject £31 million into the local economy each year. However, among the five parliamentary candidates vying for the area's seat, one expresses complete opposition, while three others voice concerns about the chosen location. Thousands of local residents have signed petitions both supporting and opposing the proposal. Conservative candidate Michelle Donelan acknowledged the merits of both viewpoints but deemed the recently concluded consultation process insufficient for a project that will "dramatically change the town forever." Wiltshire Council has yet to review the application for the 72,000 sq m regional facility, but the five candidates shared their opinions during an election debate broadcast by BBC Wiltshire. Labour's Andy Newman declared his support, citing assurances that the development would create 700 permanent skilled positions and "push up wages in the area." In contrast, Green party candidate Tina Johnston expressed outright opposition, suggesting the projected job figures were significantly inflated. Two candidates endorsed the project's concept but questioned its placement; Julia Reid (UKIP) suggested a site nearer the motorway and further from the town centre would be preferable, reducing the threat to existing shops. Finally, Liberal Democrat Duncan Hames welcomed the potential for new jobs but remained "not sure" about the suitability of the proposed site.

The 31-year-old pop star tweeted that she was denied entry into a black cab and instructed to "find an immigrant" for a ride. This alleged confrontation followed her earlier apology "on behalf of my country" concerning the squalid living conditions at the Calais Jungle camp. The Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association (LTDA) declared its condemnation of abusive behavior. On Twitter, the singer detailed the incident: "Just tried to get in a black cab with my kids. The driver looked at me and said 'find an immigrant to drive you you stupid tart'." She added that, despite a life of privilege, the encounter provided a "tiny glimpse of what it feels like to be discriminated against." Her claims were met with skepticism by some, with one Twitter user asserting it "definitely didn't happen" and another requesting the taxi's registration plate. She countered that they were "victim shaming" her, explaining, "I had both my hands full with children, couldn't get to my phone fast enough." The LTDA, representing around 5,500 London black cab drivers, stated it was urging regulator Transport for London to investigate the pop star's allegations. General secretary Steve McNamara commented: "While it is not clear whether the driver in question was a member, we take any allegation such as this extremely seriously and would condemn any cabbie who treats anyone with such disrespect and uses abusive language in this way. We've bombed your country, put you in the hands of the Taliban and now put you in danger of risking your life to get into our country. I apologise on behalf of my country. I'm sorry for what we have put you through."

The defender has agreed to a four-year contract and is projected to be part of Swansea's squad for Saturday's match against Burnley, subject to receiving international clearance. The centre-back shared his delight about becoming a Swan, noting he received advice from Michu. "It has always been my dream to play in the Premier League – it is the best in the world – and I'm grateful to Swansea for giving me this opportunity," he stated. "I inquired with Michu and Jordi Amat about the club. I had previously trained with Michu at Napoli, and during my loan spell at Getafe [in 2013], I played alongside Alvaro Vazquez, who is good friends with Jordi, so I also spoke with them. Michu informed me it's a family club and the city is very relaxed. He told me I was joining a very good club. All the feedback I've received about Swansea has been positive." The Swans will play their first home Premier League game against Burnley this Saturday, August 23, following their 2-1 away victory over Manchester United in their season opener. As Fernandez only recently resumed training after his World Cup commitments, his availability for the match is not yet confirmed. Monk praised the defender, who made 13 appearances on loan for Spanish club Getafe last season, as a valuable acquisition for the club. "He brings the pedigree of playing for Napoli at the top level and for Argentina in the World Cup. His age is very beneficial for us, as is the type of player he is. He's a good size, a very good footballer, and someone who will suit Swansea City well. Recently discovered CCTV footage shows 14-year-old Charlene Downes, last observed in Blackpool town centre. Her remains have never been recovered. Her mother, Karen, expressed disgust that the footage surfaced only now, years into the unsolved murder inquiry. Lancashire Police stated they "understood" Ms. Downes' sentiments, noting no one has been convicted for Charlene's death. This footage was released on the anniversary of Charlene's 2003 disappearance, as part of the force's "longest" running murder investigation.

Ms. Downes remarked, "I cannot comprehend why this footage was not uncovered during the prior investigation; that aspect utterly disgusts me. Nevertheless, I am pleased with the footage and hope detectives can now progress, providing us with answers. I desperately seek closure... We cannot advance with our lives, and it's simply terrible." Detective Chief Inspector Richard McCutcheon commented, "I grasp the family's perspective. We only recently located these images, which is why we are releasing them now."

The video shows Charlene and her sister Rebecca on Bank Hey Street around 15:25 GMT on November 1, 2003, heading towards the Coral Island amusement arcade. She returned home but went back to Blackpool town centre later that night, which was her last sighting. Police confirmed she was wearing the same clothes in the footage as when she disappeared. Detective Superintendent Andy Webster stated that officers are investigating connections between Charlene's case and the "broader problem of child sexual exploitation" within Blackpool. He added, "We have identified several individuals who could be either victims or perpetrators, and we intend to make arrests and prosecute abusers soon."

In 2008, a judge acquitted a man of Charlene's murder after "serious doubts" concerning evidence emerged during his second trial, following a hung jury in his initial trial. The Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) reported a year later that police evidence-gathering deficiencies led to the retrial's failure. The IPCC identified strategic and tactical mismanagement of materials, resulting in disciplinary action for several officers, with one compelled to resign in 2011. However, a 2012 Police Arbitration Tribunal subsequently reversed this resignation order.

Julia Knight, 56, denies the attempted murder of Irene Robson, 81, at Banbury's Horton Hospital in October 2014, but admits to administering the insulin. She told an Oxford Crown Court jury that she did it to avoid being discharged from the hospital herself. Ms Knight also denies intentionally causing grievous bodily harm. She informed the court she wanted her mother to remain under care and not be sent home. She stated: "I felt terrible because I knew I was going to make mum unwell. It was a stupid, stupid, thing to do. If I could go back and change it, I would." She confessed to having told a series of lies to police when questioned in January. The court heard she had forged an insulin prescription, which she collected from a Sainsbury's store in Banbury. When defence barrister Simon Mayo QC asked why she had insisted to officers she hadn't injected her mother, she replied: "I realised it was serious. I was ashamed of what I had done." Prosecutor John Price QC alleged she intended to administer a lethal dose to Ms Robson before departing the Horton. He questioned: "Why did you inject your mother with a substance which for all you knew could kill her within five minutes and do nothing for an hour and twenty minutes?" She responded: "I never intended my mother to die." Ms Knight also informed the court she had attempted suicide in 2006 by injecting herself with insulin. Ms Robson died in September, but the jury was previously told that her death was not relevant to the case and had no bearing on the issues they needed to consider. The trial continues.

The Korea Space Launch Vehicle-1 (KSLV-1) launched successfully from the Naro Space Center at 16:00 (07:00 GMT). Science Minister Lee Ju-ho confirmed that the satellite, designed for collecting climate data, had achieved its correct orbit. This launch occurs weeks after North Korea used its own three-stage rocket to place a satellite into orbit, which drew international condemnation. South Korea's 140-tonne rocket, known as Naro, was developed in collaboration with Russia, which had committed to three launch attempts with Seoul.

Prior attempts in 2009 and 2010 had failed, and this latest endeavor faced two technical postponements. However, officials announced that Wednesday's launch from the facility, located 480km (298 miles) south of Seoul, proceeded as planned, with the rocket reaching its target altitude and deploying its satellite. "After analysing various data, the Naro rocket successfully put the science satellite into designated orbit," Mr. Lee informed reporters, specifying that the satellite detached 540 seconds post-launch. He declared, "We now have leapt up a step to become a space-power nation," adding that South Korea would leverage this "overwhelming moment as a strong, dynamic force" to advance an independent space program.

The satellite, officially named Science and Technology Satellite-2C, is specifically for gathering climate data. According to Yonhap news, it is anticipated to establish contact with its ground station at 05:00 on Thursday, at which point operators will make a definitive assessment of the launch's full success. While South Korea already operates satellites in space, these were launched from other countries. In its first indigenous launch attempt in 2009, the satellite failed to separate from the rocket in orbit, and in 2010, the rocket exploded mere seconds after liftoff. The pressure for a successful launch had intensified since North Korea's rocket launch on December 12, which placed a satellite in orbit. Following that event, Pyongyang announced plans for a "high-level nuclear test" and further long-range rocket launches. The UN subsequently ruled the North Korean launch a prohibited test of missile technology and voted to expand sanctions against Pyongyang, leading to international pleas for North Korea not to proceed with the nuclear test.

He had threatened to leave the Premier League club within 24 hours if his attempt to change its name was unsuccessful, a bid the Football Association rejected in April. "When I say something, I mean it," the 75-year-old Egyptian stated on Thursday. He further mentioned that the club was listed for sale just 22 hours following the FA's decision five months prior. Allam confirmed an appeal against the name change refusal was being filed with the Court of Arbitration for Sport. He reiterated, "We stated earlier this year that the club would be for sale should our attempt to globally promote Hull Tigers as a brand name and as a playing name be blocked." "As a consequence of the FA decision on 9 April," he explained, "I announced on 10 April, within 22 hours, that Hull City is for sale." Allam, who assumed control of the club in December 2010, was questioned about his course of action if no buyer emerged and the legal appeal failed. "I will give it away. Out means I'm out. Have I ever said anything and gone back on it?" he responded. Allam confirmed that he and his son Ehab, the club's acting chief executive, would remain dedicated to the club for the immediate future. "If the appeal comes first, ok, no harm done. If the sale comes first - sold," he stated. He was vague regarding any interest from prospective buyers and implied he might remain involved if the appeal proved successful. The chairman acknowledged that manager Steve Bruce and his squad required stability, yet highlighted his significant investment during the transfer window, notably the £10m club-record signing of Uruguayan striker Abel Hernandez. Last season, Hull advanced to the FA Cup final, where they lost 3-2 to Arsenal despite taking a two-goal lead, and concluded their inaugural Premier League season since promotion from the Championship in 16th place. They currently stand ninth in the league table with four points collected from three games in the new 2014-15 season.

Nineteen-year-old Scot Higgins began his youth career at Celtic before transferring to Dens Park, where he made four appearances for Dundee last season. Former Republic of Ireland Under-21 international, Alan Power, 29, departs English League Two club Lincoln City, for whom he played in over 250 league matches. Both players have agreed to two-year contracts with the Rugby Park outfit, with Power's transfer awaiting final clearance. "It feels good to be here, as this club is definitely heading in the right direction," Higgins commented on Kilmarnock's official website.

Manager Lee McCulloch noted that Higgins aligns with Kilmarnock's philosophy of developing young players. "He progressed through Celtic's academy, an institution renowned for producing many impressive young footballers," McCulloch stated. "He gained valuable experience at Dundee during the latter half of last season and will undoubtedly improve with time, which bodes well for this club."

Power added: "I've learned a lot about the town and the club's heritage, and I can't wait to get started. The manager outlined his ambitions for this club, making it an easy decision." McCulloch recalled watching Lincoln's FA Cup quarter-final run last season, remarking on Power: "Alan featured in every one of those matches and served as the club captain. He possesses an aggressive playing style, a drive for self-improvement, and significant experience he can impart to our younger players." England faces significant back-row injury concerns, as James Haskell, Sam Jones, Mike Williams, and the adaptable Maro Itoje are all unavailable. Leveraging the identities of organizations such as NASA and the Environmental Protection Agency, these accounts are directly challenging the president, Mr. Trump, who has labeled climate change a hoax. The @RogueNASA account identifies itself as the "unofficial 'Resistance' team of NASA," stating, "Not an official NASA account. Not managed by gov't employees. Come for the facts, stay for the snark." BBC News reached out to the rogue Environmental Protection Agency account, @ActualEPAFacts. They informed us their actions aimed to ensure that "factual information about climate change and other scientific research continues to be shared during the Trump administration." Claiming to be three EPA employees, they stated they acted after a gag order prevented them from conducting interviews related to their research. Media reports have indicated that the Trump administration sought to restrict how certain government agencies, including the EPA, communicate with the public. The official EPA Twitter account has remained inactive since January 19, the day before Mr. Trump's inauguration. ActualEPAFacts expressed surprise at their significant follower growth, currently over 90,000, but also felt vulnerable due to their activities. Other rogue accounts also boast substantial follower numbers. @RogueNasa has amassed over 370,000 followers within a few days of tweeting. The rogue National Park Service account, @AltNatParkSer, has attracted even more, exceeding a million followers with fewer than 300 tweets. Similar rogue accounts exist for the US Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. These accounts employ terms like "resistance" to describe themselves and disseminate a blend of scientific data and criticism of Mr. Trump. Some individuals operating other alternative accounts, based on their tweets, also asserted they were discontented government agency employees. On Tuesday, the @AltNatParkSer account tweeted it was "being run by several active NPS rangers and friends," but by Thursday, announced a handover to a different group: activists and journalists who were former scientists. The official Twitter account of Badlands National Park in South Dakota briefly posted about global warming on Tuesday, but these tweets were subsequently deleted. The creators of @AltNatParkSer told us this incident motivated them to establish their Twitter presence. The other alternative accounts also appear to have emerged following the deletion of the Badlands tweets, while some official US national park accounts similarly tweeted about climate change on Wednesday.

A British Marine report, representing the leisure, superyacht, and small commercial marine sectors, indicated superyacht revenues hit £605 million for the year ending April 2016. Total sector revenues rose 1.6% to £3.01 billion, marking the first time the £3 billion threshold has been exceeded since 2008-2009. However, the report predicted a slowdown in growth during 2017, attributing it to the likelihood of Brexit negotiation uncertainty curbing demand. Following the financial crisis, total revenue declined, reaching its lowest point of £2.85 billion in the 2011-2012 financial year, before steadily recovering. This sales increase is largely attributed to higher revenue from engine and equipment manufacturing, alongside a significant rise in hire and charter boat sales. Exports for the year decreased by 0.7% to £882 million, yet British Marine noted that the industry had recently gained from the pound's depreciation against the dollar and euro post-referendum, enhancing purchasing power for international clients. Nevertheless, marine businesses surveyed anticipated this boost from the weaker pound to be a temporary advantage. Howard Pridding, British Marine's chief executive, stated: "The industry remains robust - revenue is growing and we are taking on more employees. Despite the post-referendum volatility impacting on business and consumer confidence, the industry remains bullish." The report reiterated that industry growth was expected to slow in 2017 "as economic volatility increases closer to and during negotiations over the UK's exit from the European Union." Sunseeker and Princess are identified as the UK's leading superyacht firms. Globally, the industry ranks as the fourth largest by turnover.

Russia's Thursday announcement of a deal establishing four "de-escalation zones" has received support from Turkey and Iran. However, the primary Syrian opposition group expressed skepticism about the agreement. Meanwhile, activists across Syria reported government aircraft striking central Hama province, alongside accounts of shelling and gunfire in various other areas. On Friday, the opposition's High Negotiations Committee (HNC) stated that the safe zones proposal was deficient in "safeguards and compliance mechanisms." Furthermore, the HNC declared its refusal to accept Iran as a guarantor of the arrangement. Staffan de Mistura, the UN special envoy for Syria, informed the BBC that the accord held significance due to its implementation by three nations capable of ensuring its success. The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) reported that Syrian fighter jets bombed rebel positions in Hama on Saturday. Reuters indicated that a rebel commander confirmed the eruption of fighting after midnight. To date, the Syrian military has offered no comment on these developments. The Russian military announced the "memorandum on the creation of de-escalation areas" following discussions held in Astana, Kazakhstan's capital. Russia's foreign ministry released the complete text of the agreement on Saturday. Its stated objective is to cease hostilities from all parties, "provide the conditions for the safe and voluntary return of refugees," and facilitate the rapid delivery of humanitarian and medical assistance. These four zones are intended to last for six months, with Russia, Iran, and Turkey tasked with finalizing their boundaries by June 4. Russian Deputy Defence Minister Alexander Fomin stated on Friday that Russian aviation had conducted no bombing raids within the four zones since May 1. However, he emphasized that Russia's air force would persist in targeting Islamic State (IS) militants in other parts of Syria. The United States voiced apprehension regarding Iran, asserting that the country had "only contributed to the violence, not stopped it." While President Bashar al-Assad's Syrian government is not a signatory, its state news agency has indicated support for the initiative. The Astana talks aimed to reinforce a frequently breached ceasefire initially established in December. Although a partial cessation of hostilities was announced late last year, violence has persisted across multiple fronts. Syria's conflict, which began in 2011, has resulted in over 300,000 fatalities.

The Senate's vote, which approved the bill by a slim margin of six votes, occurred after a 14-hour session marked by intense debate. The new law, which additionally permits same-sex couples to adopt, encountered strong resistance from the Catholic Church and other religious organizations. The party anticipates its 54 incumbent MPs will be confirmed as candidates. Only Ms. McGarry and Ms. Thomson, among Scottish MPs, opposed the election, while SNP members chose to abstain. Should they not seek re-election, the SNP must identify five candidates, three of whom would contest seats the party failed to secure in 2015. Numerous party activists have already declared their interest in running for the SNP in Glasgow East and Edinburgh West, constituencies previously held by these two women. The Scottish Labour executive is convening this weekend to establish its selection process, with leader Kezia Dugdale asserting their readiness and prior election preparations. Ian Murray, the party's only MP in Scotland, commenced his campaign to retain Edinburgh South on Friday. Scottish Secretary David Mundell subsequently initiated his campaign in Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale. Conservative MSP Douglas Ross, elected to Holyrood in 2016, stated his intention to challenge SNP depute leader Angus Robertson in Moray. The Liberal Democrats are employing all-female shortlists in several target constituencies, including Edinburgh West, with some decisions potentially being made this weekend.

A charity is calling for 10% of the 4.8 million Syrians displaced by the civil war to be resettled by year-end. Before UN negotiations on the crisis in Geneva, it pointed out that only 1.4% of these individuals have received aid thus far. Oxfam criticized the UK's plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians by 2020 as "insufficient," though Britain asserts its commitment also extends to providing regional aid. With a pledge of £2.3bn to assist those impacted by Syria's civil war humanitarian crisis, the UK stands as the second-largest bilateral donor globally, trailing only the US. While acknowledging Britain's generosity in financial aid for Syria's displaced, Oxfam contends that the nation "can and should increase" its efforts. The organization argues that economically robust nations with advanced infrastructures should bear a larger responsibility for refugees than countries like Lebanon and Jordan, which currently host thousands of Syrians. The UK-headquartered charity further stated that the Geneva conference must yield "urgent solutions, providing safe and legal pathways to a welcome" in other host countries. Oxfam analyzed the commitments made by 28 nations, all members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and signatories to the 1951 Convention on Refugees. Its findings reveal these nations promised to accept nearly 130,000 Syrian refugees, yet only 67,000 have actually arrived. The 10% of Syrian refugees Oxfam urges wealthy nations to accept by late 2016 represents the segment identified by the UN as highly vulnerable and requiring resettlement. Oxfam's analysis indicates that only Canada, Germany, and Norway have exceeded their "fair share" in resettlement pledges, a metric determined by economic size. Five additional countries—Australia, Finland, Iceland, Sweden, and New Zealand—have committed over half of their fair share. Conversely, the UK is prepared to accept 22% of its fair share, the US merely 7%, and France a meager 4%. Mark Goldring, Oxfam GB's chief executive, stated: "It is appalling that as people continue to escape Syria, the majority of countries have not offered a safe haven for the most vulnerable."

Newsweek's final print edition will be on December 31st, reflecting the broader industry trend for newspapers and magazines to transition online as traditional advertising revenues decline. Two years ago, Newsweek merged with the internet news group The Daily Beast. Its founder, Tina Brown, reported that The Daily Beast's site now attracts over 15 million unique visitors monthly, a 70% increase from the previous year. In a statement, she expressed, "Exiting print is an extremely difficult moment for all of us who love the romance of print and the unique weekly camaraderie of those hectic hours before the close on Friday night."

Newsweek first hit newsstands in 1933 as a weekly magazine covering global events. However, much like the world it chronicled for 80 years, the publishing landscape has dramatically changed, especially regarding how consumers access news. Newsweek's subscriber count has dropped from its peak of over 3 million to 1.5 million today. This decline, coupled with falling advertising revenues for traditional print media, has led Newsweek to discontinue its print edition entirely. The digital-only version, Newsweek Global, will be available via subscription. This strategy aims to tap into the 70 million US consumers who now use tablet computers, a figure that has surged from just 13 million two years ago. While this represents a substantial market, analysts caution that increased competition will make it challenging to stand out in the digital world.

A statement affirmed, "As we head for the 80th anniversary of Newsweek next year, we must sustain the journalism that gives the magazine its purpose – and embrace the all-digital future." It further clarified, "This decision is not about the quality of the brand or the journalism – that is as powerful as ever. It is about the challenging economics of print publishing and distribution." Newsweek had risen to become the second-largest US news weekly magazine, trailing only Time. However, dwindling circulation and advertising led to financial losses. The Washington Post Company sold it to Sidney Harman in August 2010, and it merged with The Daily Beast three months later. Tina Brown, also known as Lady Evans after her husband, the legendary journalist Harold Evans, was knighted, is a former editor of Vanity Fair and The New Yorker. She collaborated with Barry Diller to launch The Daily Beast in 2008, with the website's name derived from the fictional newspaper in Evelyn Waugh's 1938 novel, Scoop.

Spencer Flower asserted that his association with a social housing firm was unrelated to a 2013 discussion concerning the future of housing in east Dorset. However, he was convicted of casting an illegal vote because the company stood to gain from the proposed plan's approval. He stated, "I am surprised and disappointed that the court sided with the prosecution this morning on what I consider a technicality. The ruling was a conditional discharge for six months, which is the lowest possible sanction. The court highlighted the complete absence of any personal gain or harmful intent on my part." Flower, who also serves as an East Dorset councillor, participated in a February 2013 vote on East Dorset's core strategy while holding the position of non-executive director for Synergy Housing Ltd, a charitable social housing company from which he received an annual allowance of approximately £5,000. Although he disclosed his interest in the charity before the meeting, he was nevertheless found guilty of participating in the vote "without reasonable excuse," despite his financial stake. The core strategy encompassed redevelopment proposals for Wimborne, and even though no planning applications had been filed, it was believed that some of Synergy's social housing units could be enhanced by developers Wyatt. Flower was indicted in November and resigned as leader of Dorset County Council to contest the accusations. Two additional charges, specifically failing to declare an interest in Zebra Property Solutions Ltd to both East Dorset Council and Dorset County Council between July 1, 2012, and March 6, 2013, had previously been dismissed. Total sales saw a 7.1% increase, buoyed by the opening of 12 new stores, though this growth was less than the 11% recorded in the preceding 12 months. Sales from stores operating for over a year also rose by 5%, matching the previous year's performance. The privately-owned Swedish group identified Poland as its fastest-growing market, with sales surging approximately 20%, while Australia and Canada also demonstrated strong results. Germany remained the retailer's largest market, closely followed by the United States. Ikea plans to launch its first stores in India and Serbia this year, expanding its global presence to 340 outlets across 28 countries.
