In addition to the 12 new stores, Ikea introduced 19 "click and collect" points globally, adapting to evolving consumer behaviour. This involved a recent shift to offering some items online for either home delivery or collection, departing from its traditional model where customers load flat-pack goods themselves. In the UK, the online furniture and floorcoverings market is expanding, with sales up 15% last year, accounting for just over 12% of total expenditure, according to Verdict Retail. Earlier this year, Ikea chief executive Peter Agnefjall stated his expectation for the company to achieve annual sales of €50bn by 2020. The company recently began publishing its sales figures in September and profits in December. This year, Ikea also unveiled a museum in Almhult, Sweden, where founder Ingvar Kamprad opened the very first store in 1958, featuring many of Ikea's renowned designs and products, from meatballs to bookshelves.

In March 1981, Mr. Reagan and three others were wounded in a shooting incident outside a Washington hotel. Mr. Hinckley was subsequently found not guilty by reason of insanity but was committed for treatment at a Washington hospital. In July, a judge declared that Mr. Hinckley, now 61, no longer posed a danger to himself or the public. He had already been spending 17 days each month at his mother's Virginia home under strict conditions. The Associated Press reported his arrival at her residence after being fully released on Saturday. The shooting, occurring just weeks into Ronald Reagan's presidency, sent shockwaves worldwide. Mr. Reagan, shot in the lung, recovered. His press secretary, James Brady, suffered a head wound leading to brain damage and lifelong wheelchair use. Brady's death in 2014, at 73, was ruled a homicide, though no further charges were brought against Hinckley. Two law enforcement officers sustained less serious injuries. US District Judge Paul Friedman's judgment referenced medical assessments showing Mr. Hinckley had displayed "no symptoms of active mental illness" since 1983. He had shot the president in an apparent attempt to impress actress Jodie Foster, with whom he was obsessed and subjected to what would now be termed stalking. The court order and opinion, available on the website of the US District Court for the District of Columbia, detail the terms of Mr. Hinckley's release, along with his psychiatric history and treatment.

Emcol 2008 Ltd, the company operating the Haverfordwest abattoir, went into administration in January 2016, owing £660,000 to over 230 creditors. A director attributed this to rising operational expenses and outstanding payments due to the company. John Sollis, a dairy farmer from Newport, described the situation as a "disaster" for local individuals who were left out of pocket. Records filed with Companies House reveal that one livestock trader is owed over £107,000, with several others facing significant five-figure losses. Liquidator Gary Stones stated in his report that any distributions to unsecured creditors hinged "totally on the collection of the Irish book debt." The report further indicated that an Irish firm owed Emcol nearly £470,000. Mr. Sollis, himself owed almost £15,000 by Emcol, commented: "It was a disaster in terms of the financial losses incurred by local people and the lack of a nearby abattoir for moving livestock or injured animals. These animals now have to be transported greater distances, which adds to our expenses." The closest alternative abattoir is located in Cross Hands, Carmarthenshire. NFU Cymru President Stephen James, who is owed just over £1,000, described the abattoir's closure as a "huge blow" given its role in handling injured cattle. He noted that injured cattle now require on-farm euthanasia, leading to financial detriment for farmers. Helen Lewis, an Emcol director, confirmed the collapse stemmed from a "very significant amount of money" owed to the company by an Irish firm, alongside "escalating costs of running an abattoir." She expressed "every sympathy" for affected farmers, many of whom she knew personally.

Eighteen-year-old Ben Purdy was shot in the head in Bermondsey after confronting his girlfriend's former partner about "threatening" messages sent following their separation. Andrew Bayne, 37, of Trundleys Terrace, and his 22-year-old nephew Michael Bagnall, of Hospital Way – both residents of Lewisham – have been convicted of the murder. Their sentencing is scheduled for November 20 at the Old Bailey. The court heard that Mr. Purdy and two friends, Callum Malone and Jack Walker, confronted Bagnall. Following this "skirmish" last November, the defendants drove around Bermondsey in search of Mr. Purdy. When they located him in Mossington Gardens, Andrew Bayne shot Mr. Purdy in the head, then pointed the firearm at Callum before leaving. Mr. Purdy sustained "catastrophic injuries" and died the next day, according to court testimony. Prosecutor Crispin Aylett QC informed jurors that despite Bagnall having a new girlfriend, he remained "rankled" by his ex moving on, leading him to send her "threatening messages" via phone and Facebook. Mr. Aylett stated: "Ben evidently had enough and so that Sunday, around lunchtime, with two friends to help – Callum and Jack – the three of them decided to go and confront Michael Bagnall and settle the matter. It was undoubtedly a very foolish undertaking that ultimately cost Ben Purdy his life." Bayne was also found guilty of possessing a firearm with intent, while Bagnall was convicted of affray. As the guilty verdicts were delivered, Michael Bagnall began shouting and swearing in the dock, requiring officers to remove him.

Masai Graham secured first place with his joke: "My dad suggested I register for a donor card, he's a man after my own heart." The festival's top jokes were initially chosen by a ten-judge panel before being presented to 2,000 voters, who then selected their favorite. Previous winners of the competition, organized by TV channel Dave, include Tim Vine, Stewart Francis, and Zoe Lyon. Graham, a West Bromwich native, achieved his win after being shortlisted in both 2014 and 2015. He expressed, "It's an incredible honour to land Joke of the Fringe. Not bad for someone from West Brom!" Comedian Stuart Mitchell ranked second in the poll, with his joke: "Why is it old people say 'there's no place like home', yet when you put them in one..." Judges evaluated an average of 60 different comedy performances, sifting through over 3,600 minutes of material before deciding on their preferred gags. To ensure only the joke's quality was judged, the comedian's name or show was not disclosed during the voting process. Steve North, general manager of Dave, commented: "The Fringe is renowned for being the best place to spot new and emerging comedy talent, and although there are some returning contenders in our top 10 this year, there is a high volume of new talent which is very exciting to see." Voters also had the opportunity to pick their most "groan-worthy" jokes of the festival. These included Adam Hess's one-liner: "In France, J-Lo is called 'I have water'", and Darren Walsh's line: "What do you call three members of Abba in a French slaughterhouse? Abba trois."

The Halle Orchestra intends to establish a school in Stoke-on-Trent by 2020, catering to both primary and secondary students. This initiative involves a partnership with an academy trust for its establishment. John Summers, the orchestra's chief executive, stated that the project aims to leverage music to elevate aspirations across all academic disciplines. Envisioned in collaboration with the City Learning Trust, the proposed school would join the free schools programme, requiring approval from the Department for Education for its launch. Nevertheless, the orchestra plans to commence operations in September 2020, serving students aged seven to 19, offering masterclasses by professional musicians, concert access, and residencies with artists. Students are expected to dedicate 40% of their instructional time to specialized music classes, engaging with the Halle Choir, The Halle Youth Orchestra, and Halle for Youth ensembles. John Summers highlighted the Halle's extensive expertise in high-level performance, encompassing both instrumental coaching and choral training. He added, "Our expertise will also contribute to integrating music into the curriculum as a means of bolstering academic achievement and aspiration." Prior examples exist demonstrating such synergies between orchestral institutions and educational facilities. Notably, in Bremen, Germany, a prominent orchestra established its rehearsal spaces and administrative hub within a comprehensive school situated in a residential area. The musicians of the Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen integrated into the school's daily routine, leading to a reduction in truancy and improved academic performance.

Leading the demonstrations were individuals affected by the suicide bomb attacks at Belgium's airport and metro station, which claimed 32 lives. A Belgian broadcaster characterized the march as "calm and silent." The event was initially scheduled for one week after the March 22 attacks, but officials requested its postponement due to security threats. Relatives of victims, along with paramedics and airport staff impacted by the attacks, joined people of various religious faiths in Sunday's march. Flowers were carried in remembrance of those who perished. The procession passed through the Molenbeek neighborhood—where many alleged perpetrators of the Brussels and Paris attacks had resided—and concluded at the temporary memorial outside the city's stock exchange. Hassan Bousetta, one of the march's organizers, told the AFP news agency: "When our fellow citizens, defenceless civilians, are cut down in a cowardly attack, all citizens should stand up to express their disgust and solidarity." The turnout was less than half of the 15,000 participants organizers had hoped for. The Islamic State militant group claimed responsibility for the Brussels attacks, as well as the November 13 gun and bomb attacks in Paris that killed 130 people. Belgian police have made numerous arrests recently, yet authorities—and other security agencies across Europe—are facing pressure amid revelations of alleged failures and missed opportunities to stop the terror cell that executed both attacks.

The company announced it has received approval from Senegalese government officials to initiate an evaluation strategy. Cairn, having made two discoveries in the region last year, estimates that the fields there could contain more than one billion barrels of oil. Its evaluation efforts will commence soon with a 3D seismic survey, followed later this year by a planned multi-well exploration and appraisal program. Edinburgh-headquartered Cairn possesses a 40% stake in three offshore Senegal blocks (Sangomar Deep, Sangomar Offshore, Rufisque Offshore). Its partners include ConocoPhillips with 35% and FAR Ltd with 15%, while Petrosen, Senegal's National Oil Company, maintains a 10% interest during the exploration phase. In its most recent half-yearly report, Cairn also disclosed that it has begun international arbitration proceedings against the Indian government concerning a tax dispute. Indian authorities have prevented Cairn from accessing the value of its remaining 10% shareholding in Cairn India Limited (CIL). In March, the company was issued a tax demand for $1.6 billion, along with interest and penalties, pertaining to the 2006-07 tax year, a period when it was preparing for Cairn India's listing on the Mumbai stock exchange. Cairn has disputed this bill and intends to pursue compensation for losses incurred due to the declining value of its CIL stake. This value has fallen from $1 billion in December 2013 to $526 million as of June 30 this year, largely attributed to lower oil prices. The reduced valuation led Cairn to record a $177.1 million impairment loss in its first half, reporting a post-tax loss of $230 million, an increase from $62 million in the previous year. The company generates no revenue as its primary focus remains exploration. Nevertheless, Cairn reported a cash balance of $725 million at the close of the first half.

Mainly Shia Muslim crowds protesting corruption and security failures were dispersed with tear gas and live ammunition. Authorities in the Iraqi capital implemented a curfew, which has since been rescinded. This marked the second instance this month where demonstrators successfully breached the city's government zone. Shia cleric Moqtada Sadr denounced the deployment of force and expressed solidarity with the protesters' "peaceful [and] spontaneous uprising." Reports indicate a minimum of 50 demonstrators sustained injuries. Demonstrators charge the government with failing to implement essential reforms, particularly as it contends with its anti-Islamic State group (IS) campaign and diminishing oil income. The Sunni jihadist organization holds sway over sections of western and northern Iraq and is responsible for a series of recent assaults that have resulted in dozens of fatalities. A number of protesters successfully entered the prime minister's office and the parliament building. The Green Zone in Baghdad contains the parliament, crucial government structures, and numerous foreign embassies. Officials subsequently announced they had fully re-established control over the area and that the demonstrators had retreated. The Shia cleric and his militia, the Mehdi Army, rose to prominence following the 2003 US-led invasion of Iraq, mobilizing anti-US sentiment. Mr. Sadr's adherents frequently engaged in confrontations with US forces, whose departure the cleric consistently called for. An arrest warrant for Mr. Sadr was issued in 2004, linked to the killing of a competing cleric. His militia was also implicated in the torture and deaths of thousands of Sunnis during the sectarian violence of 2006 and 2007. Mr. Sadr sought refuge in Iran during that era. Returning from self-imposed exile to Iraq in 2011, Mr. Sadr adopted a more conciliatory stance, advocating for Iraqi unity and peace. Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi, who assumed office in 2014, has pledged to eradicate corruption and alleviate sectarian strife. He has been pushing for fundamental reforms and aims to establish a technocratic government, but has faced obstruction from lawmakers, as reported by the BBC's Jim Muir in Baghdad. The parliament is so profoundly divided that it is unable to convene, as no faction can achieve a quorum, our correspondent further notes. Iraq's system of allocating government positions has faced persistent criticism for advancing unsuitable candidates and fostering corruption. While the government maintains a delicate balance between party and religious allegiances, the nation ranks 161st out of 168 countries on Transparency International's corruption perceptions index.

Muslim cleric Mehboob Akhtar, from Stoke-on-Trent, was sentenced to 14 years in jail at Birmingham Crown Court, along with nine others, including his wife and daughter. They were found guilty of deceiving mortgage lenders to amass nearly £1 million in property, intending to "control and dominate" areas of the city. Following a trial last month, the 60-year-old, of Farman Close in Fenton, was convicted of 11 charges, including five counts of conspiracy to commit fraud and defrauding Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (HMRC) of £271,000. The court heard that Akhtar, also known as Saint Pirwali Pandariman, masterminded the conspiracy over more than a decade, between 2003 and 2014. Originally from Pakistan, he was a prominent faith leader in Fenton, having helped raise several million pounds in donations to combat poverty through the area's Darbar Unique Centre. However, Judge Stephen Eyre stated Akhtar had "let down his followers," remarking that he utilized "the prestige and devotion of others to facilitate this offending." He added that Akhtar's "role as a spiritual guide provided cover" and he financed his activities partly through donations obtained due to his spiritual position. The court learned that Akhtar kept his name off most paperwork, using his wife, daughter, and niece to apply for mortgages. When police searched homes and offices connected to the group in September 2012, they uncovered forged documents and emails related to the conspiracy. His wife, Khadija Akhtar, 54, of Hartwell Lane, Stoke, was convicted of offences including cheating HMRC and conspiracy to obtain a money transfer by deception; she was jailed for four years and three months. Akhtar's daughter, Rushbamani Akhtar, 29, received a three-and-a-half-year sentence after being convicted of entering into an arrangement to facilitate the acquisition, retention, use, or control of criminal property and conspiracy to commit fraud. Seven other individuals, including two mortgage brokers, were also sentenced after being convicted of charges such as conspiracy to defraud and obtaining money transfers by deception. Ch Supt Martin Evans, from Staffordshire Police, commented that the sentences were the result of a "very long and complex investigation."

Having earned gold four years prior, Jones is now set to defend her -57kg title at Rio 2016. The 23-year-old attributes her early drive for success to growing up in north Wales. She recalled, "I remember watching people like Kelly Holmes on the TV and that's what inspired me to want to go and get a gold medal." Jones finds it "lovely" to now be a role model, noting, "I've seen the difference from London how many girls have got into taekwondo because they've watched it on the TV." Her grandfather, Martin, encouraged her to start taekwondo at 15, aiming to "keep her off the streets." Jones remarked on the sport's growing appeal among females: "When I first started taekwondo I think there was only about four or five girls in the whole club. Now there's loads more girls and it's just amazing to see that. Sport doesn't have to be just for boys - girls are good at it too." Since her London 2012 triumph, the -57kg world number one has claimed a World Grand Prix and two European titles. Jones became Britain's first Olympic taekwondo champion by defeating China's double world champion Yuzhuo Hou in the final. She achieved the title of her nation's youngest Olympic champion just two years after securing gold at the inaugural Youth Olympics in Singapore in 2010. Flint-bred Jones acknowledges that her motivation has been "up and down" over the past four years, but she remains fixed on clinching another gold. She told BBC Wales Sport, "For London I only came into the national team in 2010, literally two years before the Olympics and no one really expected me to even go to the Olympics. I did really well that year and took the opportunity by the hands. I just went for it and it paid off." She added, "This time I've been training four years for this Olympics and ever since London my sights have been straight on the Olympics. For me the pinnacle and my goal has been the Olympics." "Wales: Olympic Dreams" will air Friday, 5 August at 19:30 BST on BBC One Wales. For those seeking inspiration in martial arts, Get Inspired offers a useful guide.

Forty-year-old Remus Hamza is accused of attacking a 20-year-old woman near Cardiff University on September 20, as she walked home alone after an evening with friends. The prosecution at Newport Crown Court alleges her extreme intoxication meant she could not have consented to sex. The defendant, a Romanian resident of Cardiff, denies the rape charge. The court heard that during her night out, the woman lost her friends and began walking home around 02:00 GMT, following Greyfriars Road, passing under an underpass by City Hall, and then along Museum Avenue. It was there that she was allegedly approached by the defendant, and the purported rape occurred behind a bush. Prosecutor Claire Pickthall informed the jury that the victim was "so drunk she can't remember the incident happening. She can't even remember him having sex with her." Pickthall asserted that this level of intoxication rendered her incapable of consent. "The actions in these circumstances amount to rape," Ms Pickthall stated, adding, "He was preying on single, drunk females." The court was told that Lee Neill, who saw Mr Hamza walking with the victim behind the National Museum of Wales, became so concerned that he followed them. Suspecting something "sinister," Mr Neill testified he took a photograph "to use as evidence." The jury heard the flash frightened Mr Hamza, who then fled. After a chase, Mr Neill lost sight of Mr Hamza and returned to the alleged victim, subsequently calling the police. However, the court heard that when officers spoke to the victim, her confusion was such that she believed Mr Neill was her assailant. He was arrested and questioned but later released. DNA evidence subsequently led police to arrest Mr Hamza, the court was informed. The woman told jurors she had consumed wine, cider, and cocktails during her night out. She stated she had little memory of her journey home or the attack but firmly asserted she would never have consented to sexual activity with a stranger. "I have a moral compass,"

Helen Bailey, 51, was found dead in a cesspit at her Royston, Hertfordshire, home in July 2016. She had not been seen since April 11. Her fiance, Ian Stewart, denies murder. Edward Farmer initially informed St Albans Crown Court that he observed her in a car in Broadstairs, Kent, between mid-April and June, though he later admitted the sighting could have taken place weeks prior. The jury was told he claimed to have seen Ms Bailey on Charlotte Street, near her holiday residence in the town, "driving what looked to be a Range Rover or that type of 4x4, a dark colour." He stated Ms Bailey was by herself, despite defense claims that she had been kidnapped by two violent men who had transported her to Broadstairs. When pressed on the date of the alleged sighting, Mr Farmer said it was "about five, maybe six weeks prior to the police interview [on July 13]." Ms Bailey was reported missing by Mr Stewart on April 15. Under cross-examination by the prosecution, Mr Farmer conceded the sighting might have occurred in March, weeks before the author's disappearance was reported. He also admitted he had "no reason at all" to reflect on the sighting until a reporter from The Sun interviewed him in June. Mr Stewart, 56, of Baldock Road, Royston, Hertfordshire, is accused of drugging his wife-to-be before suffocating her and casting her into the pit beneath the couple's garage. He denies murder, preventing a lawful burial, fraud, and three counts of perverting the course of justice. The trial continues.

At a campaign rally for Mr Trump in New Hampshire, the Republican attempted to dismiss a supporter's comment that began with: "We have a problem in this country - it's called Muslims." Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton condemned his failure to denounce "hateful rhetoric" as "disturbing and wrong." Addressing his first questioner at the Rochester event, the billionaire businessman remarked, "I like this guy." The man then stated, "We have a problem in this country called Muslims... We know our current president is one. You know he's not even an American." Mr Trump responded with a laugh, asking, "We need this question?" The man continued, "we have training camps growing where they want to kill us. That's my question: When can we get rid of them?" Rather than clarifying that Mr Obama is a Christian American, Mr Trump replied that "bad things are happening" and promised to investigate. Mrs Clinton joined the criticism on social media, tweeting: "Donald Trump not denouncing false statements about POTUS & hateful rhetoric about Muslims is disturbing & just plain wrong. Cut it out." In a statement, Democratic National Committee chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz declared that Mr Trump's "racism knows no bounds." Mr Trump's campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, tried to downplay the incident, telling US media that "all he heard was a question about training camps." He further told the Washington Post, "The media wants to make this issue about Obama. The bigger issue is that Obama is waging a war against Christians in this country." The event recalled a similar moment during the 2008 campaign when Republican nominee John McCain took the microphone from a woman who asserted she didn't trust Mr Obama because he was "an Arab." President Obama, who openly discusses his Christian faith, was born in Hawaii to an American mother and Kenyan father. However, Mr Trump was a prominent skeptic, challenging Mr Obama in 2011 to produce his birth certificate, which the president subsequently did, to disprove rumors of a Kenyan birth. Despite his lack of political experience, the businessman leads his Republican rivals in the polls with more than a year remaining until polling day.

He is also adapting to media scrutiny and articulating his policies, many of which diverge significantly from those of the preceding leader. Mr. Corbyn has strongly criticized the government's handling of the Calais migrant crisis, asserting that the UK needs to increase its efforts. He stated: "These individuals are human beings in desperate circumstances; they require our assistance and backing. A considerable number of people are traveling to Calais to deliver aid and support, and we ought to participate in the European program for both Syrian and other refugees." His stance on immigration sharply contrasts with that of the UK Independence Party, whose leader, Nigel Farage, spoke at their annual conference in Doncaster on this topic today. Farage questioned how any government could effectively plan for schooling and healthcare provisions without knowing, within a million, the future population size of the country in a few years. Furthermore, Damian Green, a Conservative MP for Kent and former immigration minister, also deems open-door immigration irresponsible. However, Mr. Corbyn maintains that immigration benefits the UK. He argued: "Our health and education services, along with much of Britain's industrial progress, have been significantly strengthened by the contributions of those who have settled here, paid taxes, worked diligently, and thus fostered our remarkable cosmopolitan society." He suggested that rather than fearing immigration, people should embrace the opportunities it presents. This message will undoubtedly be one he aims to convey to his party members gathering in Brighton this weekend. He also intends to tackle other critical concerns like the housing deficit, infrastructure investment, and his opposition to welfare reform. Beyond these points, he will seek to demonstrate his ability to connect, not just with Labour members who voted for him, but also with those supporters in the South East who deserted the party in the previous two elections. Mr. Corbyn acknowledges the challenge ahead but expressed that Labour is prepared to regain support in the South East, and he anticipates this endeavor. The Labour conference is scheduled to take place in Brighton from September 27th to 30th.

The bodies of British backpackers Miss Witheridge, 23, from Norfolk, and Mr Miller, 24, from Jersey, were discovered on a Koh Tao beach in September 2014. Burmese bar workers Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Tun were found guilty of the killings in December 2015, with an appeal court in Thailand upholding their death sentences. Lawyers for the two men now have 30 days to appeal to the Supreme Court, Thailand's final court of appeal. Last May, the pair's mothers lodged appeals at the Koh Samui court, raising concerns about the judgments, particularly the DNA evidence used in the investigation. "We don't believe the court can say beyond reasonable doubt that Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were responsible for the events which took place in September 2014," stated Andy Hall, one of the families' legal advisors. Miss Witheridge, a University of Essex student from Hemsby, and Mr Miller, a civil and structural engineering graduate, were found bludgeoned to death on the beach; a post-mortem examination also showed Miss Witheridge had been raped. Prosecutors claimed DNA evidence from cigarette butts, a condom, and the victims' bodies linked Lin and Phyo to the deaths. The men, from Myanmar, retracted their initial confessions to the offences, asserting they had been tortured by police. Their lawyers argued that DNA from a garden hoe, allegedly the murder weapon, did not match samples taken from the men. They also contended that evidence had been mishandled by police and that the pair's confessions resulted from "systematic abuse" of migrants in the area.

The Institute for Economics and Peace (IEP) reported that a specific amount is equivalent to the combined economies of Brazil, Canada, France, Germany, Spain, and the United Kingdom. The annual report also indicated a deepening disparity between the most and least peaceful nations. Iceland holds the title of the world's most peaceful country, while Syria is the least. Libya experienced the most severe deterioration in peace during 2014, according to the Australia-based IEP. The Middle East and North Africa (MENA) has now become the world's most violent region, surpassing South Asia, which held that distinction in 2013. Conflict-related deaths reached 180,000 in 2014, a significant increase from 49,000 in 2010. Fatalities from terrorism rose by 61% in 2013, resulting in nearly 18,000 lives lost, predominantly in Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Nigeria, and Syria. The IEP estimated that a 10% reduction in global violence would generate $1.43 trillion (£1.43tn). IEP Chief Executive Steve Killelea identified the "inequality with peace" worldwide as the most striking discovery. He noted that some Western European nations have achieved "historically high levels of peace," characterized by their lowest murder rates and security spending, likely in their history. Conversely, Iraq, Syria, Nigeria, South Sudan, and the Central African Republic all saw increased violence over the past year. The IEP calculated the total costs of conflict to be 13.4% of global GDP. Significant cost increases were attributed to deaths from internal conflicts, support for internally displaced people (IDPs) and refugees, UN peacekeeping efforts, and GDP losses due to conflict. The report also highlighted that the expense of assisting approximately 50 million refugees and IDPs—the highest count since WWII—had escalated by 267% since 2008, reaching $128 billion. Furthermore, the report concluded that if global violence decreased by 10%, it would effectively inject an additional $1.43 trillion into the world economy. This sum is more than six times what is needed to clear Greece's debts and three times the total earnings of about 1.1 billion of the world's poorest individuals.

A £175,000 penalty was levied against Falcon and Pointer for automated PPI calls, while Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd incurred a £50,000 fine for soliciting conversations with deceased relatives. Both entities asserted these calls were outsourced to a third party. Anne Jones, Assistant Commissioner for Wales, stated this action conveyed a "clear message to callous cold-callers." She further noted that investigations increasingly indicate Swansea as the UK's predominant cold-calling hub, with local companies exploiting "ruthless business models based on illicit practices" to generate calls that range from "irksome" to "distressing." The Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) has pursued enforcement against six firms since 2013. Falcon and Pointer's license was revoked in January 2016, despite their claim to the ICO of ceasing calls in June 2015; however, a subsequent inquiry revealed they placed an additional two million calls within the following two months. Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd, a vendor of windows, doors, and conservatories, accumulated 168 complaints over a six-month period. Ms. Jones reiterated that their measures would deliver a distinct message to Swansea's unscrupulous cold-callers: adherence to regulations is mandatory. She added that both companies had been previously contacted but exhibited a "blatant disregard for the law" by persisting with "nuisance calls," leaving many individuals "frustrated and harassed." Sandra Busby, managing director of the Welsh Contact Centre Forum, acknowledged the market's enduring need for reputable firms engaging existing clients about deals and preferential rates. She contrasted this with "disreputable, unethical companies" seeking "a quick buck," which "flagrantly disregard rules" and tarnish the industry's image. The WCCF, she stated, champions the former, promoting best practices. This recent enforcement coincided with the ICO's release of its revised Direct Marketing Guidance, designed to aid organizations in legal compliance and best practices.

The current strike action stems from the dismissal of two nurses, Kevin Gregson and Peter Hilton, following their involvement in a violent confrontation with a patient. The Prison Officers' Association (POA) stated that the pair were sacked despite using "reasonable force" against the unidentified patient. However, Mersey Care Trust, the operator of Ashworth, maintained that the available evidence left them with no alternative but to dismiss the two individuals.

The dispute at the facility, one of England and Wales' three high-security hospitals, commenced at 07:00 GMT. Steve Gillan, the POA's general secretary, expressed his belief that the public would feel outrage and strong sympathy for Mr. Hilton and Mr. Gregson, asserting that they were simply reacting to a violent incident where a patient headbutted a colleague and spat at staff. He added that the restraint measures were appropriate, causing no harm to the patient, unlike the nurses involved. Gillan emphasized that while a duty of care to patients is essential, an equivalent duty must extend to staff.

The trust conveyed its "disappointment" regarding the union's choice to initiate industrial action prior to the case being reviewed by an independent employment tribunal. In a statement, it asserted that this action was not in the best interests of their patients, carers, staff, or the communities they serve. Addressing the nurses' situation, the trust highlighted its role in caring for "some of the most complex and vulnerable adults in a hospital setting," boasting an "international and award-winning reputation" in this area. It explained that their staff are highly trained and that dismissals are never made without careful consideration. Considering the evidence, the trust felt compelled to dismiss the two staff members, having no other viable option. Rampton in Nottinghamshire and Broadmoor in Berkshire constitute the other high-security psychiatric hospitals within England and Wales.

The oil painting "Women Lovers" by Charles Blackman features two nude women resting on a bed beside a cat. Art brokerage firm Mossgreen tried to promote it on Facebook, but the social media network rejected it for "advertising adult products or services." Paul Summer, Mossgreen's chief executive, called the decision "ridiculous." He told the BBC, "This is a very beautiful image that is not overtly sexual in any shape or form. It's like going back to the 1950s. It's ridiculous to censor this sort of thing." Facebook maintained its decision was final, although Mossgreen has since reposted images of the work. Facebook stated in a message, "Such ads lead to negative user sentiment and we have zero tolerance towards such advertisements." Last month, a French teacher took Facebook to court after his account was suspended for posting an image of a nude woman painted by 19th-century artist Gustave Courbet. Mr. Summer noted that "Women Lovers" was expected to sell for more than A$45,000 (£28,000; $34,000) at an upcoming auction. "Nobody said a single thing until Facebook suddenly decided it was going to offend somebody," he commented. "I don't know who they're protecting because I have two teenage daughters myself and if I said to them that this painting has been banned I think they would have laughed at me." Blackman, currently 88, has been called "the last man standing" from a prominent era in Australian art. His contemporaries included modernist painters Arthur Boyd, Sidney Nolan, and Albert Tucker. Last year, Sotheby's Australia sold Blackman's painting "The Game of Chess" for A$1.78 million. "Charles Blackman is the most well-regarded and respected living Australian artist," Mr. Summer affirmed.

Set at the height of the Cold War, "The Spy Who Came In From The Cold" is being adapted by Oscar-winning writer Simon Beaufoy, known for "Slumdog Millionaire." The story centers on Alec Leamas, a British intelligence officer with a drinking problem, whose East Berlin network is in ruins, its agents either fleeing or dead, victims of East German counter-intelligence officer Hans-Dieter Mundt. Recalled to London, Leamas is offered a chance for revenge. John le Carre expressed his "great excitement" for the show, which will be broadcast on BBC One. This series marks another co-production with US network AMC, following their successful joint effort on "The Night Manager," a drama for which Tom Hiddleston, Hugh Laurie, and Olivia Colman all won Golden Globes, and the show itself was nominated for best mini-series or TV film. "The Spy Who Came In From The Cold" is set in 1962, mere months after the construction of the Berlin Wall. The novel, written in 1963, was previously made into a film starring Richard Burton in 1965, and le Carre stated he was "looking forward to seeing it on screen again," adding, "I have great confidence in the team." Beaufoy commented, "It's incredibly exciting to be working on the best Cold War spy story ever written." The show will be produced by The Ink Factory, the company behind "The Night Manager," in association with Character 7. Piers Wenger, controller of BBC Drama, noted: "Following the huge global success of The Night Manager, it's a privilege to announce that John le Carre will return to BBC One with one of the best spy thrillers ever written."

Oxford University Press (OUP) analyzed over 120,421 short stories written by children aged between five and thirteen years old, which were submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. According to OUP, new technology is increasingly central to children's lives, but their way of writing about it is rapidly transforming. Words such as email, mobile, and Facebook are declining in use, being replaced by terms like Instagram, Snapchat, and emoji. Furthermore, the word "television" has now been superseded by "phone." The report also highlighted the sudden emergence of the hashtag symbol (#) in children's sentences, becoming commonplace for adding extra meaning or comment at the end of a sentence, as seen in #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta at the Oxford University Press stated, "This has been a significant change in usage in this year, 2015. Children have extended its [#] use from a simple prefix or as a search term for Twitter to an editorial device to add drama or comment." Other technology terms on the endangered list include iPod, mp3, and Blackberry, now largely replaced by iPhone, the chat app WhatsApp, and the messaging site ooVoo. #keepup One of the most frequent plotlines in the short story competition involved achieving sudden internet fame after posting a YouTube video. Instead of writing about watching videos, stories often revolved around the number of hits, shares, and likes their own videos received. #makesabetterstory Among the most popular characters were Cinderella, footballer Lionel Messi, Snow White, Adolf Hitler, and Wayne Rooney. Researchers were surprised by the number of children who wrote using mythological characters such as Zeus, the Minotaur, and Hercules. #theyloveZeus As a source for stories, World War One was common, and global events in Ukraine and Syria were popular, though significantly less so than the most frequent current affairs topic, Ebola. The search for a cure was a recurring plot. New words also appeared, including "wellysaurus," "gloomful," and "Stegasuarez," a mutant monster hybrid of a Stegosaurus and footballer Luis Suarez. #itbites The competition winners will be announced on Friday on The Chris Evans Breakfast Show on BBC Radio 2, broadcast live from St James's Palace, with the DJ having enlisted the support of the Duchess of Cornwall.

The 23-year-old Heracles attacker stated he was anticipating the completion of a transfer to the Championship team. Slade, however, denied the reports' accuracy but conceded he had expressed some interest in the player "a while back." "As far as I know, that's not a path we'll be taking," he commented. Weghorst, a Netherlands Under-21 international, started his career at FC Emmen prior to moving to Heracles in 2014. Heracles chairman Jam Smit thought a transfer fee for Weghorst, who has also been connected with Celtic, had been reached with Cardiff. "It seems all the pressure and rumors concerning the player originate from the Netherlands," Slade further stated. "An initial query was made some time ago. That is all I can disclose." Slade aims to secure as many as three new players in this transfer window to bolster the Bluebirds' challenge for a Championship play-off spot, with the team presently four points adrift of the top six. A forward is a probable addition, following last season's leading goalscorer Kenwyne Jones' move to Al Jazira in the United Arab Emirates. The Trinidad and Tobago international asserted on social media that he wasn't offered a new contract by the club, but Slade countered this, saying, "I'm quite certain there was an ongoing discussion involving Kenwyne's representatives, Kenwyne personally, and [chief executive] Ken Choo and the board of directors." He also refuted assertions by Rotherham Manager Neil Redfearn that the two teams were negotiating a possible transfer for Alex Revell. Revell, aged 32, moved to Cardiff from Rotherham in January 2015, netting two goals in 15 league appearances for the Bluebirds. "We've already lost a target man centre forward," Slade stated. "We must be cautious not to hinder ourselves and ensure we possess sufficient players across all positions and areas of the field." Cardiff will host League One side Shrewsbury Town this Sunday in the FA Cup third round, with defender Lee Peltier highly questionable due to sickness.

The new walk-in service is designed to decrease doctor appointments and help curb the overuse of antibiotics, according to NHS England. It is hoped this initiative could lead to fewer GP visits, potentially saving the NHS millions of pounds annually. However, pharmacies are concerned that cuts in sector funding could undermine the program. The Sore Throat Test and Treat service, which underwent trials in 35 Boots pharmacies, determines if an illness is virally caused – meaning medication will not be effective – or a bacterial infection. Results from a throat swab, which measures sugars on the tongue, are available within five minutes. Patients requiring antibiotics will receive prescriptions directly from the pharmacist, bypassing the need to see a GP. NHS chief executive Simon Stevens stated the scheme would be implemented nationwide during the coming year. Dr. Adam Roberts, a microbiologist at University College London specializing in antibiotic resistance, told the BBC it was "quite an innovative step." He remarked: "Anything that reduces our reliance and our inappropriate use of antibiotics is a good thing." He added that initial data from the kit showed only 36 prescriptions were issued out of approximately 360 individuals, which is a "massive reduction." Claire Ward, chairwoman of Pharmacy Voice, the industry's representative body, welcomed the rollout, describing it as the "kind of thing community pharmacies should be undertaking." Nevertheless, she warned that service cutbacks could prevent the scheme from succeeding. In October, the Pharmaceutical Services Negotiating Committee informed the BBC that the government had proposed a 12% funding cut from December, though the Department of Health indicated no final decision had been reached. This throat test is among eight medical innovations being introduced to help the NHS modernize in the face of increasing demand. Sir Bruce Keogh, NHS England's national medical director, affirmed that "innovation is not an option but a necessity if we are to build a sustainable NHS." He further stated that the selected innovations "have the potential to deliver better value for the taxpayer whilst making patient interactions with the NHS safer and more personal."

Researchers at the University of Bristol report that Japan's Sakurajima volcano, situated on Kyushu island, presents a "growing threat." The volcano, located 49 km (30 miles) from the Sendai nuclear plant and near Kagoshima, a city of 600,000, last had a fatal eruption in 1914, killing 58 people. Japan, part of the Pacific "Ring of Fire," has over 100 volcanoes. Sakurajima frequently emits ash and experiences numerous small explosions annually, with its most recent eruption occurring in February. Japanese authorities closely monitor it, assigning it Level 3 out of 5 in Japan's volcanic warning system, which advises against approaching the volcano. Dr. James Hickey, the study's lead author, now with the University of Exeter's Camborne School of Mines, stated, "The 1914 eruption measured about 1.5km cubed in volume." He added, "From our data we think it would take around 130 years for the volcano to store the same amount of magma for another eruption of a similar size- meaning we are around 25 years away." A report on the volcano's activity, published Tuesday, involved teams from Bristol University and the Sakurajima Volcano Research Centre. Their research indicated that 14 million cubic metres of magma accumulate annually, enough to fill London's Wembley Stadium 3.5 times. They concluded that magma accumulation outpaces its expulsion through smaller eruptions, suggesting a significant eruption is probable within the next 30 years. These conclusions were drawn from novel methods for studying and modeling the volcano's magma reservoir. Scientists hope these findings will assist authorities in preparing for major eruptions. Dr. Hickey remarked, "We know that being forewarned means we are forearmed and providing essential information for local authorities can potentially help save lives if an eruption was imminent." Dr. Haruhisa Nakamichi, Associate Professor at Kyoto University's Disaster Prevention Research Institute, noted that new evacuation plans are already in place. He said, "It is already passed by 100 years since the 1914 eruption, less than 30 years is left until a next expected big eruption. Kagoshima city office has prepared a new evacuation plan from Sakurajima."
